The assignment of computer resources to current and waiting jobs; for example, the assignment of main memory, input/output devices, and auxiliary storage to jobs executing concurrently in a computer system. See also: dynamic resource allocation; storage allocation.
The computer equipment, programs, documentation, services, facilities, supplies, and personnel available for a given purpose. See also: computer resource allocation.
It embraces all aspects of design and use of computer and data processing.
Note: P610.9 [161 defines terminology pertaining to computer security.
Detailed, pre-programmed instructions that control and coordinate the work of computer hardware and firmware components in an information system. See Application , Operating system .
A functionally or logically distinct part of a computer software configuration item, typically an aggregate of two or more software units.

An aggregation of software that is designated for configuration management and treated as a single entity in the configuration management process. Contrast with: hardware configuration item. See also: configuration item.
(1) It includes computer hardwares, software, human ware etc. for converting raw data into a useful information. (2) A system containing one or more computers and associated software.
See: word.
Application of the computer to any activity that was previously carried out by some other means.
To use the computing machine for processing the data.
A facility designed to provide computer services to a variety of users through the operation of computers and auxiliary hardware and through services provided by the facility's staff.
To bring together a set of characters, generally as a part of a programme.

(1) (IEEE Std 1002-1987 [91) The period of time in the software development cycle during which the user needs are described and evaluated through documentation (for example, statement of needs, interface control; notice of revision; specification change notice; waiver.

(1) It refers to the ability of computer to do several things at once.(2) Refers to the occurrence of two or more events or activities within the same specified interval of time. (3) Pertaining to the occurrence of two or more activities within the same interval of time, achieved either by interleaving the activities or by simultaneous execution. Syn: parallel (2). Contrast with: simultaneous.
Means to perform two or more data processing tasks within a specified interval.
Some printers offer a condensed typeface. The characters are squashed up resulting in more being printed across the line.
See: status code.
See: conditional jump.
A jump that takes place only when specified conditions are met. Contrast with: unconditional jump.

(1) The requirements, design, and implementation, that constitute a specific software system or any of its components. (2) It is an assembly of machines which are interconnected and are programmed to operate as a system. (3) The arrangement of a computer system or component as defined by the number, nature, and interconnections of its constituent parts. (4) In configuration management, the functional and physical characteristics of hardware or software as set forth in technical documentation or achieved in a product. See also: configuration item; form, fit and function; version.
See: functional configuration audit; physical configuration audit.

(1) The process of approving, coordinating, implementing, documenting, and verifying changes to configuration items.(2) An element of configuration management, consisting of the evaluation, coordination, approval or disapproval, and implementation of changes to configuration items after formal establishment of their configuration identification. Syn: change control. Contrast with: config uration identification; configuration status accounting. See also: configuration control board; deviation; engineering change; configuration control board (CCB). A group of people responsible for evaluating and approving or disapproving proposed changes to configuration items, and for ensuring implementation of approved changes. Syn: change control board. See also: configuration control.
See: block diagram.

(1) An element of configuration management, consisting of selecting the configuration items for a system and recording their functional and physical characteristics in technical documentation. Contrast with: configuration control; configuration status accounting. (2) The current approved technical documentation for a configuration item as set forth in specifications, drawings, associated lists, and documents referenced therein. See also: allocated configuration identification; functional configuration identification; product configuration identification; baseline. (3) The process of creating, assigning, and affixing designators to configuration items. Designators may be alphabetical, numeric, or mixtures of both.

A document used in configuration management, providing an accounting of the configuration items that make up a product. See also: configuration item development record; configuration status accounting.

(1) A product, hardware or software component, subcomponent, or collection of subcomponents which is to be placed under formal configuration management.(2) An aggregation of hardware, software, or both, that is designated for configuration management and treated as a single entity in the configuration management process. See also: hardware configuration item; computer softwan? configuration item; configuration identification; critical item.

A document used in configuration management, describing the development status of a configuration item based on the results of configuration audits and design reviews. See also: configuration index; configuration status accounting.

(1) A process that effectively controls the coordination and implementation of changes to software components. (2) The process of identifying the configuration items in a system, controlling the release and change of those items throughout the system life cycle; recording and reporting the status of the items and associated change requests; and verifying the completeness and correctness of the items.(3) A discipline applying technical and administra-
Refers to an AND operation.
Refers to the cable that is used for transferring electrical impulses between two pieces of equipment.
It refers to the coupling device that provides an electrical and or mechanical junction between a cable and a chassis or enclosure.
Pertaining to the occurrence of two sequential events or items without the intervention of any other event or item; that is, one immediately after the other.
The degree of uniformity, standardization, and freedom from contradiction among the documents or parts of a system or component. See also: traceability.
A check performed to make sure that the specific input data fall within a predetermined set of criterion.
It refers to that portion of a computer which is used for communication between operators or maintenance engineers and the computer mostly with the help of displays and manual controls.

(1) Refers to the value that remains unchanged during a program. (2) A quantity or data item whose value cannot change; for example, the data item FIVE, with an unchanging value of 5. Contrast with: variable. See also: figurative constant; literal.

The period of time in the life cycle of a system or component during which hardware failures occur at an approximately uniform rate. Contrast with: early-failure period; wearout-failure period. See also: bathtub curve.
(1) A restriction, limitation, or regulation that limits a given course of action. (2) Any condition that limits the solutions to a problem.

A type of coupling in which some or all of the contents of one software module are included in the contents of another module. Contrast with: commonenvironment coupling; control coupling; data coupling; hybrid coupling; pathological coupling.
It is a condition that occurs when two central processing units try to control the same device simultaneously.
Given a software process, the action of testing the flow of information into and out of a model representing the process for coherence and consistency.
Overview data flow diagram depicting an entire system as a single process with its major inputs and outputs.

A storage allocation technique in which programs or data to be stored are allocated a block of storage of equal or greater size, so that logically contiguous programs and data are assigned physically contiguous storage locations. Contrast with: paging (1). Std 610.12-1990 configuration status accounting. An element of configuration management, consisting of the recording and reporting of information needed to manage a configuration effectively. This information includes a listing of the approved configuration identification, the status of proposed changes to the configuration, and the implementation status of approved changes. Contrast with: configuration control; configuration identification. See also: configuration index; configuration item development record.
Any plan for recovery of the computer information system after any type of emergencies or disasters.
A loop that has no exit.
It is used in computer graphics. It means the creation of the outline of a body, mass or figure.

Software obtained through a contractual agreement between a contracting agency and an external organization. Contracted software is custom software. [contrast with developed software and procured software]
The NWC agency, either design or production, which has prime responsibility for and authority over the software development effort.
The organization under contract or tasking agreement with the contracting agency to perform any part of the software development effort.
See: code breakpoint.
Refers to the character that on being transmitted starts or controls a device

A type of coupling in which one software module communicates information to another module for the explicit purpose of influencing the latter module's execution. Contrast with: common-environment coupling; content coupling; data coupling; hybrid coupling; pathological coupling.
Data that select an operating mode, direct the sequential flow of a program, or otherwise directly influence the operation of software; for example, a loop control variable.
The sequence in which operations are performed during the execution of a computer program. Syn: flow of control. Contrast with: data flow.

(1) A graphical representation of a system showing the flow of control signals throughout the system. (2) A diagram that depicts the set of all possible sequences in which operations may be performed during the execution of a system or program. Types include box diagram, flowchart, inputprocess-output chart, state diagram. Contrast with: data flow diagram. See also: call graph; S t r u c t w - e chart.
See: execution trace.
See: job control language.
See: supervisory program.
It is a register that hold the address of either the current instruction or the next instruction that has to be carried out by the computer.
A method or means used to mitigate hazards and reduce risk.

A program statement that selects among alternative sets of program statements or affects the order in which operations are performed. For example, ifthen- else, case. Contrast with: assignment statement; declaration.
In a microprogrammed computer, the computer memory in which microprograms reside. See also: microword; nanostore.
It refers to the use of computers and micro electronics to control external devices, generally as a part of automated systems.
It is the part of the central processing unit. It makes the computer to carry out, sequentially, each instruction of a programme.
See: loop-control variable.

An environment characterized by fully-developed and wellunderstood processes, documented and available work instructions, adequate equipment, trained personnel, and any required special working conditions or specifications.

(1) Methods, formats, and patterns adopted for the presentation of information to provide consistency and understanding. (2) (IEEE Std 983-1986 [71) Requirements employed to prescribe a disciplined uniform approach to providing consistency in a software product, that is, uniform patterns or forms for arranging data. See also: practices; standards.

Pertaining to an interactive system or mode of operation in which the interaction between the user and the system resembles a human dialog. Contrast with: batch. See also: interactive; on-line; real time.
See: incremental compiler.

(1) The process of changing from the old system to the new system. (2) Modification of existing software to enable it to operate with similar functional capability in a different environment; for example, converting a program from Fortran to Ada, converting a program that runs on one computer to run on another.
It is a step by step directory that is issued by manufacturers and gives all instructions about installing and using a program.

(1) To read data from a source, leaving the source data unchanged, and to write the same data elsewhere in a physical form that may differ from that of the source. For example, to copy data from a magnetic disk onto a magnetic tape. Contrast with: move. (2) The result of a copy process as in (1). For example, a copy of a data file.
It is a high level programming language for real time applications. It was developed by Royal Rader Establishment (England).
See: memory dump.
It refers to a magnetic memory. It consists of rows and columns of small iron rings. They can be magnetised in one of the two directions clockwise or anti- clockwise thus giving a binary storage.

(1) Refers to those instructions that are used for transferring a set of inputs directly into output. (2) A routine that begins execution at the point at which operation was last suspended, and that is not required to return control to the program or subprogram that called it. Contrast with: subroutine.
Maintenance performed to correct faults in hardware or software. Contrast with: adaptive maintenance; perfective maintenance.

(1) The degree to which a system or component is free from faults in its specification, design, and implementation. (2) The degree to which software, documentation, or other items meet specified requirements. (3) The degree to which software, documentation, or other items meet user needs and expectations, whether specified or not.
See: pmf of correctness.

(1) A variable used in a program to keep track of the number of times an event has occurred. (2) A variable used to record the number of occurrences of a given event during the execution of a computer program; for example, a variable that records the number of times a loop is executed.

(1) A measure of the amount of information shared between two modules. (2) A measure of the interdependence among modules in a computer program. [Contrast with cohesion]. (3) The manner and degree of interdependence between software modules. Types include common-environment coupling, content coupling, control coupling, data coupling, hybrid coupling, and pathological coupling. Contrast with: cohesion.
Acronym for computer program component. See: computer software component.
Acronym for computer program configuration item. See: computer software configuration item.
Critical Path Method.
Computer Protection Program Manager.
Carriage Return.

(1) It refers to the event in which the computer breaks down because of malfunctioning of hardware or due to pressing of break key during programming. (2) The sudden and complete failure of a computer system or component. See also: hard failure.
Cyclic Redundancy Check.

(1) A review conducted to verify that the detailed design of one or more configuration items satisfy specified requirements; to establish the compatibility among the configuration items and other items of equipment, facilities, software, and personnel; to assess risk areas for each configuration item; and, as applicable, to assess the results of producibility analyses, review preliminary hardware product specifications, evaluate preliminary test planning, and evaluate the adequacy of preliminary operation and support documents. See also: preliminary design review; system design review. (2) A review as in (1) of any hardware or software Component.

In configuration management, an item within a configuration item that, because of special engineering or logistic considerations, requires an approved specification to establish technical or inventory control at the component level.

A system development approach in which the most critical aspects of a system are implemented first. The critical piece may be defined in terms of services provided, degree of risk, difficulty, or other criteria. See also: bottom-up; top-down.
(IEEE Std 1012-1986 [123) Software whose failure could have an impact on safety, or could cause large financial or social loss.

A set of specific operational conditions shaped by the business environment that are believed to significantly impact the success potential of an organization or business function. In a software development effort, critical success factors are composed of assumptions and dependencies that are generally outside the control of the development team.
The degree of impact that a requirement, module, error, fault, failure, or other item has on the development or operation of a system. Syn: severity.
In computer graphics it refers to cut off some part of an image.
An assembler that executes on one computer but generates machine code for a different computer.
To check the computing by two different methods.
A compiler that executes on one computer but generates machine code for a different computer.

A software tool that accepts as input the source code of a computer program and produces as output a listing that identifies each of the program's variables, labels, and other identifiers and indicates which statements in the program define, set, or use each one. Syn: crossreferencer.
A list that identifies each of the variables, labels, and other identifiers in a computer program and indicates which statements in the program define, set, or use each one.
See: cross-reference generator.
Means interference between signals on different circuits.
It is a mini stabilize circuit that protects a computer system from dangerously high voltage surges.
Chip Select.
Acronym for computer software compo-
Computer Software Configuration Item. [see configuration item]
Acronym for computer software confignent.
Computer Society of India
Computer Systems Security Officer.
Computing Telecommunications Security Organization.
See: call (3).
Computer Using Educators.

(IEEE Std 1002-1987 [91) A standard that describes the characteristics of a course of study on a body of knowledge that is offered by an educational institution. cycle. (1) A period of time during which a set of events is completed. See also: software development cycle; software life cycle. (2) A set of operations that is repeated regularly in the same sequence, possibly with variations in each repetition; for example, a computer's read cycle. See also: pass.
Generally a rectangle the size of a capital letter which appears on the screen of a VDU to indicate the current display position.
Keys provided on key board of a terminal used to position the cursor on the display screen.

The number of subject matter experts for each Use Case (UC) in an application under development. This project risk factor is considered low when more than one SME is available perUC. A high risk ensues when outside SMEs are involved with a software development effort. See operational data area, subject matter expert, Use Case .
Refers to a family of super computers and mainframes manufactured by control data corporation.
It is identical to management by exception based on exception reporting the basic elements of which may be analyzed.
It is a systematic study comparing the control communication and information handling capabilities of higher animals and machines
Human with an electronic or electro-mechanical robot part.

(1) The process of suspending the operation of a central processing unit for one or more cycles to permit the occurrence of other operations, such as transferring data from main memory in response to an output request from an input/output controller. (2) It is a technique that permits a peripheral device to temporary computer control of the I/O bus and in this way permits an access to the computer's internal memory.
A storage allocation technique in which each search for a suitable block of storage begins with the block following the one last allocated.
It is an arrangement that enables the propagation of signals along a bus. The assignment priorities are automatically selected.

It is a letter quality printer. It has a wheel with arms like the petals on a daisy. One key board character is placed on each petal. The wheel is rotated so that correct sequence of characters are struck with hammer as they pass through 12o clock position. The quality of print is better as compared to that of dotmatrix printer. It is some what slow and prints at a speed of about 50 characters per second and is generally noisy.
It is a type of cathode ray tube. It seems black on being turned off. It produces a good contrast to video displays.
Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency.
Direct Access Storage Device.
Dynamic Address Translation.

(1) Streams of raw facts representing events before they have been organized and arranged into a form that people can understand and use. See information . (2) It is a general term that refers to numbers. digits, characters, symbols that are accepted, stored and processed by a computer. Data is generally used as opposing concept to text. (3) A representation of facts, concepts, or instructions in a manner suitable for communication, interpretation, or processing by humans or by automatic means. See also: data type.Note: IEEE Std 610.5-1990 [21 defines terminology pertaining to data management. (4) Sometimes used as a synonym for documentation.

(1) The process of extracting the essential characteristics of data by defining data types and their associated functional characteristics and disregarding representation details. See also: encapsulation; information hiding. (2) The result of the process in (1).
It refers to a comprehensive collection of file or libraries of data.
A collection or arrangement of data or data files.
It refers to a break in the flow of data from one computer to another. Such a break occurs during manual transfer of information from one computer to another.

A breakpoint that is initiated when a specified data item is accessed. Syn: storage breakpoint. Contrast with: code breakpoint. See also: dynamic breakpoint; epilog breakpoint; programmable breakpoint; prolog breakpoint; static breakpoint.

A bus that transfers information in the form of electronic signals from one location to another in a computer. The address of the location is indicated by the signals that travel along the address bus.
It refers to the ways wherein data is collected or captured for being processed.
It is a punched or magnetic card containing one or more details.
(IEEE Std 1008-1987 [lo]) An inherent, possibly accidental, trait, quality, or property of data (for example, arrival rates, formats, value ranges, or relationships between field values).
It is the process where in the data is subjected to various checks to find out invalid data before it is processed
It includes all the electro-mechanic and electronic equipment that. is used in transmitting data from one place to another.
It refers. to the process of transmitting data between equipment, generally quite apart.
It refers to the process of removal of undesirable characters and gaps before storage or data transmission.
It refers to the collection of ? data at an intermediate point from various low and medium speed lines, for transmission across high speed lines

It is the process where by the process of execution of various jobs are controlled. It is done by preparing machine readable data from source documents, planning the execution of jobs and distributing the output in a desired form.
It is a block on storage medium that contains information about name and description etc. about the file.
It refers to the condition in which the data, either residing on a medium (e.g. floppy) is physically or involuntarily changed.

A type of coupling in which output from one software module serves as input to another module. Syn: input-output coupling. Contrast with: common-environment coupling, content coupling; control coupling; hybrid coupling; pathological coupling.
Note: This term is defined in IEEE Std 610.5-1990 [23.
A statement of the characteristics of basic elements of information. These characteristics may include, but are not limited to, type, range, structure, and value.

(1) A list of the names of all data elements used in a software system, together with the relevant properties of those items. (2) A set of definitions of data flows and data elements referred to in a data flow diagram. (3) A structured description of database objects such as tables, indexes, views and fields, with further descriptions of field types, default values and other characteristics. (4) It includes list of all the fields, files, systems with storage structure and accessing strategy.
It is a floppy disk that is set aside for the only purpose of holding data files. It contains no programme files.
See field .
A data representation of a real world object or concept. Usually represented as a row in a database table, such as information about a specific Product in inventory.
It is the process of putting data into a computer for processing.
An exception that occurs when a program attempts to use or access data incorrectly. See also: addressing exception; operation exception; overflow exception; pmtection exception; underflow exception.
The sequence in which data transfer, use, and transformation are performed during the execution of a computer program.

(1) A graphical representation of a system, showing the logical flow of data and the processes transforming data, together with the sinks, sources, and stores for data. (2) A primary tool in structured analysis that graphically illustrates a system's component processes and the flow of data between them. (3) A diagram that depicts data sources, data sinks, data storage, and processes performed on data as nodes, and logical flow of data as links between the nodes. Syn: data flowchart; data flow graph.
See: variable trace.
See: data flow diagram.
It refers to the structure of data into sets and subsets in an ordered sequence.
User documentation that describes, in a worksheet format, the required and optional input data for a system or component. See also: user manual.
It is a measure of data management performance calculated by the rate of undetected -errors. It is lost by data corruption.
It refers to pilferage or leakage of data from a system.
It refers to the automatic collecting of data by a machine for computer. Such a data is stored for later analysis
It is the process that is used for commands in high level language for adding, deleting, sorting, merging, modifying or retrieving data in a file or a database.
It refers to any of the storage devices used in a computer, e.g. paper tape, magnetic tape or disks, punched cards etc.
It is a hand held magnetic scanning device for reading magnetically encoded data on tags and labels.
It refers to the operation of collection of collecting, storing, processing and transmitting data. It is the general term used for business application of the computer
It is any device that is capable of performing operations on data, may be analog computer, a desk calculator or digital computer.
It is the rate at which a channel carries data. It is measured in bits per second.
It refers to the protection of data from any accidental or malicious modifications. The Data Protection Act was passed by parliament in 1986.

(1) It refers to the device that allows transmission of data over communication lines by encoding the data at one end and decoding it at the other end Data sharing It is a method used by computer users at several modes of accessing data at single modes. (2) Information organized for analysis or used as the basis for a decision, and in a form suitable for processing by a computer.
It refers to the high capacity storage medium receiving and responding to data transmitted by a data source.
It is the digital electronic device that is responsible for originating the transmission of data.
A physical or logical relationship among data elements, designed to support specific data manipulation functions.

(1) A graphical representation of the ordering and accessibility relationships among items of data without regard to their actual storage configuration. (2) A diagram that depicts a set of data elements, their attributes, and the logical relationships among them. Contrast with: data flow diagram. See also: entity-relationship diagram.

A software design technique in which the architecture of a system is derived from analysis of the structure of the data sets with which the system must deal. See also: input-processoutput; modular decomposition; objectoriented design; rapid prototyping; stepwise refinement; structure clash; structured design; transaction analysis; transform analysis.
It is a point in a computer system from which data can be entered or retrieved.
It refers to sending of data from one computer or device to another

(1) A description of how the computer is to interpret the data stored in a particular field. Data types can include text or character string data, integer or floating point numeric data, dates, date/time stamps, true/false values, or Binary Large Objects (BLOBs) which can be used to store images, video, or documents. (2) A class of data, characterized by the members of the class and the operations that can be applied to them. For example, character type, enumeration type, integer type, logical type, real type. See also: strong typing.
A fault that causes a failure in response to some particular pattern of data. Syn: pattern-sensitive fault. Contrast with: program-sensitive fault.

(1) A set of related data tables and other database objects, such as a data dictionary, that are organized as a group. A collection of data organized to service many applications at the same time. (2) It refers to an inter-related data records or files of structured data that are stored in a computer. It is in a direct access mode and provides all the data allocated to a subject. (3) A collection of interrelated data stored together in one or more computerized files. Note: IEEE Std 610.5-1990 121 defines terminology pertaining to databases.
Person(s) responsible for the administrative functions of databases, such as system security, user access, performance and capacity management, and backup and restoration functions.
A component of a database, such as a table or view.
It refers to the process of recording the times and dates of when computer files are accessed, modified and created.
Singular for data.
Database Administrator. The person(s) who provide technical training and support in data base technology and resource administration.

(1) Database Management System. (2) Software used to create and maintain a database and enable individual business applications to extract the data they need without having to create separate files or data definitions for their own use.
Data Control Block.
Data Communications Equipment.
Direct Distance Dialing.
Distributed Data Processing.
A situation in which computer processing is suspended because two or more devices or processes are each awaiting resources assigned to the others. See also: lockout.
See: disassembler.
To separate the parts of a block. Contrast with: block (2).

(1) It is the art of removing errors or bugs from a computer programme. (2) To detect, locate, and correct faults in a computer program. Techniques include use of breakpoints, desk checking, dumps, inspection, reversible execution, single-step operation, and traces.
It involves the detection, location arid removal of mistakes in a computer program.

It refers to some special features in a high level interpretive language or special program routines in low level ones which help the programmer in rewriting the errors that were introduced in a developing program.
Digital Equipment Corporation.
To separate into two or more parts.
It is the process of decoding of any information from previously enciphered data.
It refers to the computer process of taking anyone of many alternative courses of action based on specific conditions.
It is a diamond-shaped symbol used in a flow chart to indicate a choice in direction.
A table used to show sets of conditions and the actions resulting from them.
Grouping and stocking punched cards.

A non-exe cut a ble program statement that affects the assembler or compiler's interpretation of other statements in the program. For example, a statement that identifies a name, specifies what the name represents, and, possibly, assigns it an initial value. Contrast with: assignment statement; control statement. See also: pseudo instruction.
A nonprocedural language that permits the user to declare a set of facts and to express queries or problems that use these facts. See also: interactive language; rule-based language.
It is the device that changes data from one coded form into another.
To arrange copies of continuous form in sets and remove the carbon paper from them.
To translate a compiled computer program from its machine language version into a form that resembles, but may not be identical to, the original high order language program. Contrast with: compile.
A software tool that decompiles computer programs.
The process of making software modules more independent of one another to decrease the impact of changes to, and errors in, the individual modules. See also: COUpling.
To break the code that has been used in secret messages. Computers are quite helpful for this purpose.
It is the process of taking an encrypted message and reconstructing from it the original meaningful message.
It refers to an item of hardware that is used for just one application or task e.g., a telegraph line reserved for transmission of digital 'data only will be called a dedicated telephone channel.

(1) An initial value assigned to a field by the application when a new database record is created. Used to facilitate data entry by pre-entering common values for the user. DELIVERABLE A specific work product, such as requirements or design documentation, produced during a task or activity to validate successful completion of the task or activity. Sometimes, actual software is delivered. (2) For speeding up the decisions, a programmer generally sets the machine 'to allocate the most likely instruction or value'. The user can thus accept this default instruction or value without thinking of various other possibilities. However he is free to make some other alternative decision.
A character or set of characters used to denote the beginning or end of a group of related bits, characters, words, or statements.

An element of the software design which is designated to be provided to the requester. Examples of potential deliverables include planning documents, draft or final design documents, test results, code, user manuals, etc.
Release of a system or component to its customer or intended user. See also: software life cycle; system life cycle.
A storage allocation technique in which pages are transferred from auxiliary storage to main storage only when those pages are needed. Contrast with: anticipatory paging.
In software design, the process of combining related software modules, usually to optimize system performance. See also: downward compression; lateral compression; upward compression.

A dynamic analysis technique that relies on observation of system or component behavior during execution, without need for post-execution analysis, to detect errors, violations of development standards, and other problems. See also: testing.
In this notation we count in tens using decimals. The digits 0 to 9 are used in units column before we carry over to the tens column.
It is a list where in all possible cells are filled. No record can be added to such a list until format of record is changed.
It refers to a technique that is used to enhance the three dimensional appearance of a two- dimensional object.
It is a list that permits insertion and deletions at both ends.
A data type whose members and operations are taken from those of another data type according to some specified rule. See also: subtype.
(IEEE Std 1002-1987 [SI) A standard that describes the characteristics of product information or procedures provided to help understand, test, install, operate, or maintain the product.

(1) The process of defining the architecture, components, interfaces, and other characteristics of a system or component. See also: architectural design; preliminary design; detailed design. (2) The result of the process in (1).

A document that describes the design of a system or component. Typical contents include system or component architecture, control logic, data structures, input/ output formats, interface descriptions, and algorithms. Syn: design document; design specification. See also: product specification. Contrast with: requirements specification. Contrast with: code review; formal qualification review; requirements review; test readiness review.
A less formal term for Software Design Specification (SDS).

(1) A specification for a software object or component that fulfills, or assists in the fulfillment of a functional element. A part of the system design specification. (2) (IEEE Std 990-1987 [81) A basic component or building block in a design.
(IEEE Std 1016-1987 [131) An element (component) of a design that is structurally and functionally distinct from other elements and that is separately named and referenced.
See: inspection.

A specification language with special constructs and, sometimes, verification protocols, used to develop, analyze, and document a hardware or software design. Types include hardware design language, program design language. See also: requirements specification language.
(IEEE Std 829-1983 [51) The design decomposition of the software item (for example, system, subsystem, program, or module).

The period of time in the software life cycle during which the designs for architecture, software components, interfaces, and data are created, documented, and verified to satisfy requirements. See also: detailed design; preliminary design.
Characteristics governing the quality of the software design. The design factors are correctness, maintainability, and verifiability.

A requirement that specifies or constrains the design of a system or system component. Contrast with: functional re quiremen t; implementation requirement; interface requirement; performance requirement; physical requirement.

A process or meeting during which a system, hardware, or software design is presented to project personnel, managers, users, customers, or other interested parties for comment or approval. Types include critical design review, preliminary design specification. See: design description.
A stage in the software development lifecycle that produces the functional and system design specifications for the application under development.
(IEEE Std 1002-1987 [91) A standard that describes the characteristics of a design or a design description of data or program components.
(IEEE Std 990-1987 [81) A logically related collection of design elements. In an Ada PDL, a design unit is represented by an Ada compilation unit.
(IEEE Std 1016-1987 [131) A subset of design entity attribute information that is specifically suited to the needs of a software project activity.
are created for all facets of a configuration item, such as hardware, schematics, code, requirements, test plans, test results, and design documentation.

(1) It is the process involving a manual checking of a program with a small set of sample data before executing it on the computer. Such a check helps to detect any errors in logic or syntax of computer. (2) A static analysis technique in which code listings, test results, or other documentation are visually examined, usually by the person who generated them, to identify errors, violations of development standards, or other problems. See also: inspection; walk-through.
It is a complete computer system (i.e. microprocessor, input and output devices, storage etc.)that is designed to fit on the top of a desk.
It is a system of producing professional-quality reports, book-lets, magazines etc. on a computer and peripherals.
It refers to the device or address that receives the data during data transfer operation.
The address of the device or storage location to which data is to be transferred. Contrust with: source address.
A read operation that alters the data in the accessed location. Contrast with: nondestructive read.

(1) The process of refining and expanding the preliminary design of a system or component to the extent that the design is sufficiently complete to be implemented. See also: software development pmcess. (2) The result of the process in (1).
Software designed and developed in-house by an agency within the NWC. [contrast with contracted software and procured software]
The organization or individual primarily responsible for the design and implementation activities for the software system.

The availability of developers and other resources with appropriate skills is a significant factor in project success. When developers and resources are readily available, the likelihood of project success is very high. Most development firms manage multiple projects, allowing some contention between projects for developers and other resources. This project risk factor is considered high when one or more developers with specific skill sets, or resources with specific capabilities, need to be acquired before the project can continue.

The initial sets of specifications, design, and other documents that collectively define the software being developed to meet the approved requirements. The development baseline reflects a particular stage of development of the software product.
See: software development cycle.
See: software development cycle.
See: requirements specification.

A stage in the software development lifecycle during which a software product is created from the design specifications and testing is performed on the individual software units produced. See Unit testing . Also referred to as the programming stage or implementation stage.

Formal or informal testing conducted during the development of a system or component, usually in the development environment by the developer. Contrast with: acceptance testing; operational testing. See also: qualification testing. operator manual; programmer manual; support manual; user manual.
See: developmental configuration.

In configuration management, the software and associated technical documentation that define the evolving configuration of a computer software configuration item during development. Note: The developmental configuration is under the developer's control, and therefore is not called a baseline. Contrast with: allocated baseline; functional baseline; product baseline.

(1) A departure from a specified requirement. (2) A written authorization, granted prior to the manufacture of an item, to depart from a particular performance or design requirement for a specific number of units or a specific period of time. Note: Unlike an engineering change, a deviation does not require revision of the documentation defining the affected item. See also: config uration control. Contrast with: engineering change; waiver.

(1) It is an item of computer hardware that communicates- either one way or both ways-with a computer e.g. printers, modems etc. (2) A mechanism or piece of equipment designed to serve a purpose or perform a function.
Acronym for data flow diagram.
To trace or search malfunctions in computing equipment and to debug mistakes in programs and systems.
Pertaining to the detection and isolation of faults or failures; for example, a diagnostic message, a diagnostic manual.

A document that presents the information necessary to execute diagnostic procedures for a system or component, identify malfunctions, and remedy those malfunctions. Typically described are the diagnostic features of the system or component and the diagnostic tools available for its support. See also: installation manual; diagonal microinstruction. A microinstruction capable of specifying a limited number of simultaneous operations needed to carry out a machine language instruction. Note: Diagonal microinstructions fall, in size and functionality, between horizontal microinstructions and vertical microinstructions. The designation diagonal refers to this compromise rather than to any physical characteristic of the microinstruction. Contrast with: horizontal microinstruction; vertical microinstruction.
See: variable trace.
See: change dump.
See: directed graph.
An address that identifies the storage location of an operand. Syn: onelevel address. Contrast with: immediate data; indirect address; n-level address. See also: direct instruction.
See: open subroutine.
A computer instruction that contains the direct addresses of its operands. Contrast with: immediate instruction; indirect instruction. See also: absolute instruction; effective instruction.
A graph (sense 2) in which direction is implied in the internode connections. Syn: digraph. Contrast with: undirected graph.
A list of data items and information about those data items. Note: IEEE Std 610.5-1990 [21 defines Data Management terms. shows their relationships to one another. See also: specification tree.
To translate an assembled computer program from its machine language version into a form that resembles, but may not be identical to, the original assembly language program. Contrast with: assemble.
A software tool that disassembles computer programs. Syn: deassembler.
A data type whose members can assume any of a set of distinct values. A discrete type may be an enumeration type or an integer type.
A peripheral device consisting of a disk drive and one or more read/write units.
Scheduling of CPU to select next task and get it ready for processing, for optimum utilization of computer
The picture generated by a program or operating system.
It refers to any undesired change in the wave form of an electric signal passing through s circuit, including the transmission medium.

A network of computer hardware and software located at several geographically separated locations. Each individual location is able to meet their computing needs independently, but may share information with other locations when necessary.
Refers to combination of dots o different colours so as to produce altogether new colours by a program.

In fault tolerance, realization of the same function by different means. For example, use of different processors, storage media, programming languages, algorithms, or development teams. See also: software diversity.

(1) A medium, and the information recorded on it, that generally has permanence and can be read by a person or a machine. Examples in software engineering include project plans, specifications, test plans, user manuals. (2) To create a document as in (1). (3) To add comments to a computer program.
It is an input device computer where by forms having marks in certain positions are read by a machine.

(1) (also referred to as software documentation, computer program documentation) The comprehensive written description of software in various forms and levels of detail that clearly defines its requirements, content, composition, design, performance, testing, use, and maintenance. (2) Information made available to: 1) assist end-users in the operation of a software application, generally in the form of on-line help, or 2) assist developers in locating the correct root procedure or method for a specific software function, generally in the form of an implementation map. Note that printed manuals are rarely delivered with software anymore; on-line documentation is more consistently available from within the application and is easier to use. (3) The instructions, tutorials trouble-shooting guides and information that should accompany commercial hardware and software products.(4) A collection of documents on a given subject. (5) Any written or pictorial information describing, defining, specifying, reporting, or certifying activities, requirements, procedures, or results. (6) The process of generating or revising a document. (7) The management of documents, including identification, acquisition, processing, storage, and dissemination.
A diagram that depicts all of the documents for a given system and Software Documentation User c Program Data Fig 9 Documentation Tree double-operand instruction. See: two-address instruction.

The acceptance of material by the DOE based upon the results of DOE quality assurance activities and production agency quality operations.
It is a piece of hardware that contains one or more Read Only Memory devices (ROMs).
It refers to any substance that is used as an impurity during doping process e.g. Arsenic, Phosphorus etc
It is the process of introducing impurities 'c during manufacture of semi- conductor devices.
Disk Operating System. It is the critical component of a computer. It is a software and provides the consistent rules for organizing and storing information.
It is the distance in millimeters between individual dots on a monitor screen.
It refers to a character formed by dots on visual display units or by printer in matrix formation printed so close that it gives the impression of being solid.
It is a printer that forms characters on paper by printing a pattern of dots. This type of printer is very verastile and is generally used. Such a printer can be used to produce photographs as well.
It refers to the use of two stores or buffers in a computer where one can be analyzed while the other is being filled or vice-versa.
It is a stepped method of converting binary numbers into their decimal equivalents.
Pertaining to a system or component that is not operational or has been taken out of service. Contrast with: up. See also: busy; crash; idle.
The period of time during which a system or component is not operational or has been taken out of service. Contrast with: up time. See also: busy time; idle time; mean time to repair; set-up time.
To get computer information or a program from a source and load it into the computers memory or storage system.

Pertaining to hardware or software that is compatible with an earlier or less complex version of itself; for example, a program that handles files created by an earlier version of itself.Contrast with: upward compatible.
In software design, a form of demodularization in which a superordinate module is copied into the body of a subordinate module. Contrast with: lateral compression; upward compression.

Data Processing Management Association.
It is one of the three connecting terminals of a field effect transistor (FET) , the other two being the source and the gate

The formal system for defining Sandia-designed or controlled product and test equipment. This system can be used by all NWC agencies and includes standards for the content of engineering drawings, as well as methods for their creation, storage, duplication, and maintenance.
It refers to a change in quantity of output of an electric circuit taking place because of ageing/sirling.
It is the mechanical 'part of the storage system. The most common being floppy disk drive.

(1) A software module that invokes and, perhaps, controls and monitors the execution of one or more other software modules. See also: test driver. (2) A computer program that controls a peripheral device and, sometimes, reformats data for transfer to and from the device.

It refers to a terminal whose capability is inferior in comparison to those of smart or intelligent terminal. Such a terminal is only used to send commands and receive display information from a computer.
It is the process of copying the data in a section of memory and sending it to a peripheral device or to a backing store.
It is a link that permits simultaneous two way communication.
It refers to the practice of keeping duplicate devices as stand by units in case of failure in a primary unit to increase redundancy.
An if-then-else construct in which processing is specified for both outcomes of the branch. Contrast with: monadic selective construct.
Pertaining to an event or process that occurs during computer program execution; for example, dynamic analysis, dynamic binding. Contrast with: static.
See: dynamic resource allocation.
The process of evaluating a system or component based on its behavior during execution. Contrast with: static analysis. See also: demonstration; testing.
Binding performed during the execution of a computer program. Contrast with: static binding.

A breakpoint whose predefined initiation event is a runtime characteristic of the program, such as the execution of any twenty source statements. Contrast with: static breakpoint. See also: code breakpoint; data breakpoint; epilog breakpoint; programmable breakpoint; prolog breakpoint.
A buffering technique in which the buffer allocated to a computer program varies during program execution, based on current need. Contrast with: simple buffering.
It refers to the ability to transfer data between different application packages that are resident in a machine, even when one of the packages is not in use.
A dump that is produced during the execution of a computer program.
An error that is dependent on the time-varying nature of an input. Contrast with: static error.
It is a form of random access memory. It needs a constant memory refresh in order to keep the contents intact.
Relocation of a computer program during its execution.
A computer resource allocation technique in which the resources assigned to a program vary during program execution, based on current need.
The process of restructuring a database, data structure, computer program, or set of system components during program execution.
Such a stop jumps the program into an indefinite loop and simultaneously indicates that some thing is wrong. The machine resumes operation only after an interaction with the operator.
A storage allocation technique in which the storage assigned to a computer program varies during program execution, based on the current needs of the program and of other executing programs.

The period of time in the life cycle of a system or component during which hardware failures occur at a decreasing rate as problems are detected and repaired. Contrast with: constant-failure period; wearout-failure period. Syn: burnin period. See also: bathtub curve.
It is a software package that is used for word processing. It is not as powerful as WORDSTAR.

Extended Binary Coded Decimal Interchange.

(1) To return a transmitted signal to its source, often with a delay to indicate that the signal is a reflection rather than the original. (2) A returned signal, as in (1). (3) The return to the screen of the transmitted data so that it can be checked against the original. When echo is not desired the echo suppressor is used to eliminate the echo.
Electronics Components Industries Association (India).
Emitter Coupled Logic.
Electronic Computer Oriented Mail.

(1) Acronym for engineering change ProposaL edit. To modify the form or format of computer code, data, or documentation; for example, to insert, rearrange, or delete characters. editor. See: text editor, linkage editor. (2) In configuration management, a proposed engineering change and the documentation by which the change is described and suggested. See also: configuration control.
Slot shaped socket that connects a circuit card to a another card or chasis.
It involves the task of changing and improving a program. It can be accomplished by adding or removing instructions or by modification of the data.
It is a mode of operation for a terminal in which files consisting of programs and/or data may be modified.

Exchangeable Disk Store.
Electronic Delay Storage Automatic Calculator.
Electronic Discrete Variable Automatic Computer.
Electrically Erasable Programmable Read Only Memory.

The address that results from performing any required indexing, indirect addressing, or other address modification on a specified address. Note: If the specified address requires no modification, it is also the effective address. See also: generated address; indirect address; relative address. (2) The process of developing or using a model as in (1).

The computer instruction that results from performing any required indexing, indirect addressing, or other modification on the addresses in a specified computer instruction. Note: If the specified instruction requires no modification, it is also the effective instruction. See also: absolute instruction; direct instruction; immediate instruction; indirect instruction.
Refers to those devices that interact with and change their local environment.

(1) Pertaining to a flow of data or control from a superordinate module tb a subordinate module in a software system. Contrast with: afferent. (2) The extent to which software performs its intended functions by using a minimum of computing resources. (3) The degree to which a system or component performs its designated functions with minimum consumption of resources. See also: execution efficiency; storage efficiency.

A software development technique based on the concept of team, rather than individual, responsibility for program development. Its purpose is to prevent individual programmers from identifying so closely with their work that objective evaluation is impaired.
Electronic Industries Association.
It is a buffer that is capable of holding a variable amount of data depending upon the need at any given time.
The system of providing data relating to orders and other forms by exchanging tape or by using phone lines, electronic mail and computers.
To transfer funds electronically from one account to another with computerized equipment.
It refers to process of sending, receiving, storing and forwarding textual messages in digital form through telecommunication channels.
It is a non-impact printer. It prints dotmatrix characters one at a time with the help of wires or pins that supply electrical charge in the desired patterns on to an aluminium coated paper.
It refers to a storage medium, as for the screen of a CRT, that stores bits in the form of charged areas.
It is a high-speed printer. It makes use of heated elements to create characters as matrices of small dots on heat sensitive paper.
It refers to an item of data with in an array or a matrix.
See also: multiple inclusive selective construct.
A computer system that is part of a larger system and performs some of the requirements of that system; for example, a computer system used in an aircraft or rapid transit system.
Software that is part of a larger system and performs some of the requirements of that system; for example, software used in an aircraft or rapid transit system.
Electro-Magnetic Interference
It is a type of logic circuit generally used in high speed computers.
To imitate one hardware system with another with the help of an electronic attachment. The imitating system behaves exactly in the same way as the system imitated

(1) To act exactly like another e.g., a computer that emulates another has the same physical, electrical properties. (2) A model that accepts the same inputs and produces the same outputs as a given system. See also: simulation.

(1) It is a device that is used in conjunction with special routine and it enable the computer in executing the machine language programs written for another computer of dissimilar design without any prior translation. It generally consists of stored logic in a read only storage unit, that interprets and stimulates the functions of each instruction in the original computers program. (2) A device, computer program, or system that accepts the same inputs and produces the same outputs as a given system. See also: simulator.

A software development technique that consists of isolating a system function or a set of data and operations on those data within a module and providing precise specifications for the module. See also: data abstraction; information hiding.
It means to change the information according to certain well defined rules so that it can not be read without the knowledge of these rules.
Means to convert data into a code.
It is the circuit that carries out the work of encoding.

(1) The coding and scrambling of messages to prevent unauthorized access to or understanding of the data being stored or transmitted.(2) It refers to the process of changing a message in such a way that it becomes incomprehensible to anyone except to those who have the key to its decryption.
It is a programming statement that signals the end of statement to be executed at the end of the program

(1) The individual or organization who will ultimately use the final software product.(2) It refers to any person who uses a computer with software. Programmers are generally not considered as end-users.
The review of a deliverable for functional accuracy by a Subject Matter Expert who is familiar with the software product under design or development. See Review .
It refers to the hand attached to the manipulator of robot. It is also called gripper.
A code used when working with a stream of data when it is necessary to indicate the end of various items.
The application of a systematic, disciplined, quantifiable approach to structures, machines, products, systems, or processes.

In configuration management, an alteration in the configuration of a configuration item or other designated item after formal establishment of its configuration identification. See also: configuration control; engineering change proposal. Contrast with: deviation; waiver.

A document which defines requirements to perform a Qualification Evaluation (QE), lists all planned QE activities, personnel, required data, scheduling information, data analyses, and product quantities (as applicable) required for conducting the specific QE, and which documents the specific results obtained during the QE. QEs can be conducted on hardware, manufacturing technology, software or firmware, acceptance equipment hardware and software, or on weapon system test programs. (These functions were previously referred to as Tool-Made-Sample (TMS), Qualification Sample (QS), Equipment Qualification (EQ), and Test Program Validation (TPV))
A change to an existing system to satisfy newly specified user requirements.
A key on some key board that is used to transfer the lines of data that have just been typed to the computer for processing and to return the cursor to the first-position on the next line.

(1) A collection of attributes related to and describing a specific subject, such as Products. (2) Refers to any object that has some meaning for a specific application. (3) In computer programming, any item that can be named or denoted in a program. For example, a data item, program statement, or subprogram.
(IEEE Std 1016-1987 D31) A named characteristic or property of a design entity. It provides a statement of fact about the entity.

(1) A diagram illustrating the relationship between various entities in a database. (2) A diagram that depicts a set of real-world entities and the logical relationships among them. Syn: entity-relationship map. See also: data structure diagram.
See: entityrelationship diagram.
See: entry point.
(1) It refers to the process of inputting data. (2) See: entry point. similar characteristics of a system. Syn: error prediction model.
A point in a software module at which execution of the module can begin. Contrast with: exit. Syn: entrance; entry. See also: reentry point.

A discrete data type whose members can assume values that are explicitly defined by the programmer. For example, a data type called COLORS with possible values RED, BLUE, and YELLOW. Contrast with: character type; integer type; logical type; real type.
End Of Block.
End of File.
End of Job.
End of Message.
End of Transmission

A breakpoint that is initiated upon exit from a given program or routine. Syn: postamble breakpoint. Contrast with: prolog breakpoint. See also: code breakpoint; data breakpoint; dynamic breakpoint; programmable breakpoint; static breakpoint.
Emergency Power off.
Erasable Programmable Read Only Memory. A Semiconductor memory device (chip) which can be programmed with machine language, erased, and subsequently reprogrammed.
Electrically Powered Read Only Memory.
A class of data that is processed, or has been processed, using an identical set of rules and procedures. [see also boundary value and boundary value analysis]
Two or more faults that result in the same failure mode.
It is a method of storing information that permits you to erase the same information e.g., magnetic tape, floppy tape etc
To remove data from storage without replacing it.
It is the study of the physical relationships between people and their work environment

(1) The difference between a computed, observed, or measured value or condition and the true, specified, or theoretically correct value or condition. For example, a difference of 30 meters between a computed result and the correct result. (2) An incorrect step, process, or data definition. For example, an incorrect instruction in a computer program. (3) An incorrect result. For example, a computed result of 12 when the correct result is 10. (4) A human action that produces an incorrect result. For example, an incorrect action on the part of a programmer or operator. Note: While all four definitions are commonly used, one distinction assigns definition 1 to the word error, definition 2 to the word fault,definition 3 to the word failure, and definition 4 to the word mistake. See a2so: dynamic error; fatal error; indigenous error; semantic error; syntactic error; static error; transient error. (5) Refers to any discrepancy between a computed, observed or measured quantity and the true or theoretical value. Error can be due to mistakes in programming or due to faulty equipment or human mistakes.

In software evaluation, a model used to estimate or predict the number of remaining faults, required test time, and error prediction. A quantitative statement about the expected number or nature of faults in a system or component. See a1so:error model; error seeding.
See: error model.

The process of intentionally adding known faults to those already in a computer program for the purpose of monitoring the rate of detection and removal, and estimating the number of faults remaining in the program. Syn: bug seeding; fault seeding. See also: indigenous error.
The ability of a system or component to continue normal operation despite the presence of erroneous inputs. See also: fault tolerance; robustness.
A programmer can put a message on the screen to indicate what has gone wrong when ever an error occurs. Such a wording is called error-message.
It refers to a character that causes the character that follows it to be interpreted differently from those preceding it.
An appraisal or evaluation of the amount of time and resources required to develop software.
The process of determining whether an item or activity meets specified criteria.
It refers to an occurrence during the execution of a task.
It is a page making DTP software.
An event that causes suspension of normal program execution. Types include addressing exception, data exception, operation exception, overflow exception, protection exception, underflow exception.

(1) A binary data file that can be run by the operating system to perform a specific set of functions. In Windows, executables carry the extension .EXE and can be launched by double-clicking on them. (2) A computer program (code) which is ready to be loaded into the computer. All necessary compiling, assembling, linking, etc. has been completed, and the binary code is ready for execution. [contrast with source program]
(1) Means to run a program on computer. (2) To carry out an instruction, process, or computer program.
The degree to which a system or component performs its designated functions with minimum consumption of time. See also: execution time; storage efficiency.
See: monitor (1).

The amount of elapsed time or processor time used in executing a computer program. Note: Processor time is usually less than elapsed time because the processor may be idle (for example, awaiting needed computer resources) or employed on other tasks during the execution of a program. Syn: run time (3); running time. See also: overhead time.

A record of the sequence of instructions executed during the execution of a computer program. Often takes the form of a list of code labels encountered as the executes. Syn: code trace; controlflow trace. See also: retrospective trace; subroutine trace; symbolic trace; variable trace.
See: supervisory program.
See: supervisory program.
See: supervisor state.
It is a device that enable users to create and debug programs and hardware interfaces manually.

(1) It is that point in an algorithm or a program from which control is transferred some where else. (2) A point in a software module at which execution of the module can terminate. Contrast with: entry point. See also: return.
It is the address of the instruction in a program that transfers control to a subroutine.
A routine that receives control when a specified event, such as an error, occurs.

(1) The capacity to increase software capabilities or performance by enhancing current functions or by adding new functions or data.See: extendability. (2) The ease with which a system or component can be modified to increase its storage or functional capacity. Syn: expandability; extensibility. See also: flexibility; maintainability.
See: absolute address.
Additional features added to a programming language or computer system.

In database applications, an external interface is a defined process and data structure used to exchange data with other systems. For example, an order processing application may have an interface to exchange data with an external accounting system.

The level of complexity associated with an external interface. A simple interface is generally unidirectional, with limited, stable logic defining the structure of the exchanged data. A standard export from a database to a spreadsheet is considered a simple interface. A complex interface may be bi-directional, or may have extensive, adaptive logic defining the structure of the exchanged data. The transmission of labor data to a corporate payroll system, with its attendant validation and transaction confirmation requirements, is considered a complex interface.
Reference to a symbol defined in another routine.
The process of selecting various components from a storage unit.
It is a piece of software It is used on commodore-54 home computer. It develops the child's talent for creative design.
Face Analysis Comparison and Eliminatiof1 System

It refers to the scanning of a document and converting the shading into signals that can be transmitted with the help of wires or radio waves. A copy of the original document is then created with the help of these signals.
(1) The process of decomposing a system into a hierarchy of modules. See also: modular decomposition. (2) The process of removing a function from a module and placing it into a module of its own.

(1) It is a system designed to avoid catastrophe, possibly at the expense of convenience. (2) Pertaining to a system or component that automatically places itself in a safe operating mode in the event of a failure; for example, a traffic light that reverts to blinking red in all directions when normal operation fails. Contrast with: fail soft. See also: fault secure; fault tolerance.

Pertaining to a system or component that continues to provide partial operational capability in the event of certain failures; for example, a traffic light that continues to alternate between red and green if the yellow light fails. Contrast with: fail safe. See also: fault secure; fault tolerance.

(1) The inability of a software system to perform a required function. (2) The inability of a system or component to perform its required functions within specified performance requirements. Note: The fault tolerance discipline distinguishes between a human action (a mistake), its manifestation (a hardware or software fault), the result of the fault (a failure), and the amount by which the result is incorrect (the error). See also: crash; dependent failure; exception; failure mode; failure rate; hard failure; incipient failure; independent failure; random failure; soft failure; stuck failure.
The physical or functional manifestation of a failure. For example, a system in failure mode may be characterized by slow operation, incorrect outputs, or complete termination of execution.
The number of failures in a specified time period. Failure rate is a means of measuring the reliability of a device, such as a hard disk.

The ratio of the number of failures of a given category to a given unit of measure; for example, failures per unit of time, failures per number of transactions, failures per number of computer runs. Syn: failure ratio.
See: failure rate.
It refers to the number of input lines (mostly fixed) to a logic gate or logic device.
An error that causes the system or applica- tion program to crash that is, to fail abruptly with no hope of recovery.
(1) It prevents the execution of a program and causes processing to cease. (2) An error that results in the complete inability of a system or component to function.

(1) A defect in a hardware device or component; for example, a short circuit or broken wire. (2) An incorrect step, process, or data definition in a computer program. Note: This definition is used primarily by the fault tolerance discipline. In common usage, the terms error and bugs are used to express this meaning. See also: data-sensitive fault; program sensitive fault; equivalent faults; fault masking; intermittent fault. (3) (also referred to as bug) An unintentional condition that causes software system to be unable to perform a required function (i.e., causes a failure).

1. A physical defect, such as a loose connection, that prevents a system or device from operating as it should. 2. A programming error that can cause the soft- ware to fail. 3. As page fault, an attempt to access a page of virtual memory that is not mapped to a physical address. See also page fault.
A list of faults in a system or component, and the tests that have been designed to detect them.
A condition in which one fault prevents the detection of another.
Pertaining to a system or component in which no failures are produced from a prescribed set of faults. See also: fault tolerance; fail safe; fail soft.
See: error seeding.

Individual fields are charac- terized by their maximum length and the type of data (for example, alphabetic, numeric, or financial) that can be placed in them. 1. The breaking apart of files as they are stored by the operating system into small, sepa- rate segments on disk. The condition is a natural conse- quence of enlarging files and saving them on a crowded disk that no longer contains contiguous blocks of free space large enough to hold them. File fragmentation is not an integrity problem, although it can eventually slow read and write access times if the disk is very full and storage is badly fragmented. Software products are available for redistributing (optimizing) file storage to reduce fragmen- tation. 2. In a database, a situation in which records are not stored in their optimal access sequence because of accu- mulated additions and deletions of records. Most database systems offer or contain utility programs that resequence records to improve efficiency of access and to aggregate free space occupied by deleted records.
