Office Automation System. A combination of software applications such as word processing, electronic mail, and calendaring, that is designed to increase the productivity of data workers in the office.
It is a multiuser programme system that is used for operating a number of micro-computer system It is like many a camels using one oasis.

(1) Pertaining to the outcome of an assembly or compilation process. See also: object code; object module; object program. (2) A program constant or variable. (3) An encapsulation of data and services that manipulate that data. See also: objectoriented design.

(1) Program instructions that have been translated into machine language so that they can be executed by the computer. See executable . (2) It is a machine Code that is understood by the computer. It contains data as well as the instructions. It is actually a high level language source program. It is produced by a compiler, with or without an assembler. (3) Computer instructions and data definitions in a form output by an assembler or compiler. An object program is made up of object code. Contrast with: source code.
It refers to a set of punched cards which represent the machine language equivalent of a source desk.
It refers to the language that can program, the micro-compressor or computer, directly written in a binary code.[See: target language.]

(1) The machine language program which is output from an assembler or compiler and is processed by a linkage editor before execution. (2) A computer program or subprogram that is the output of an assembler or compiler. See also: load module; object program.

(1) A compiled or assembled version of the source code that is ready to be loaded into a computer.(2) The machine language program obtained from source program. (3) A computer program that is the output of an assembler or compiler. Contrast with: source program. Syn: target program. See also: object module.

A software development technique in which a system or component is expressed in terms of objects and connections between those objects. See also: data structure-centered design; inputprocess- output; modular decomposition; rapid prototyping; stepwise refinement; structured design; transaction analysis; transform analysis.
A programming language that allows the user to express a program in terms of objects and messages between those objects. Examples include Smalltalk and LOGO.
A standard that describes the characteristics of the general areas of work or profession.
Optical Character Recognition.
Refers to a situation that has a choice of eight possible values or states e.g. octal number system.

In this system counting is done in 'eights' and not in 'tens'. It makes use of the digits 0,1,2,3,4,5,6 and 7. The units, tens and hundred position in denary system become 15, 85, 645 positions respectively in octal notation.
It is the number system based on 8.
It is a Radix point in a mixed octal numeral that separates the fractional part from the integer part e.g. 96.47, the octal point is between 6 and 4
Open Document Architecture refers to a set of standards that aim at facilitating mail and document connectivity between systems which support text and graphics.

Open Database Connectivity . A set of software drivers and database functions that allow different applications to access client/server RDBMSs, desktop database files, text files, and spreadsheets for the purpose of exchanging and manipulating database information.
It is an error checking system. In it an extra bit is added to a byte to make the number of ones in the byte odd. Even pairty makes an even number.
It is an instrument that is used for recording the distances that are covered by at bicycle or some motor vehicle.
Original Equipment Manufacturer.
Pertaining to a device or process that is not under the direct control of the central processing unit of a computer. Contrast with: on-line (2).
Refers to those devices that are not in direct control of the CPU.
That storage media which is not under control of CPU.
Those operations that are generally carried out to prepare data to be entered" into a computer.
Means to output data to some peripheral device.
Refers to the circular symbol that is used on flow chart for linking a line of flow on one page with its continuation on some different page.
Refers to a fully finished mass produced hardware or software product that is readily available at the show room.
It refers to the application of computers for performing various office tasks.

(1) The difference between the loaded origin and the assembled origin of a computer program. Syn: relocation factor. (2) A number that must be added to a relative address to determine the address of the storage location to be accessed. This number may be the difference defined in (1) or another number defined in the program. See also: base address; indexed address; relative address; self-relative address.

Online Analytical Processing. A technology that operates on nonrelational, multidimensional databases often known as data cubes. Data cubes are often created via specialized processing from relational databases. The objective of OLAP is to allow the end user to perform highly flexible analysis and reporting.
A micro-computer manufacturer, produces a range of equipment for office use.
One Line Query.

Online Transaction Processing(OLTP) most commonly refers to large-scale database applications, such as order entry and payroll systems, which use transaction processing to assure data integrity. See transaction .
On Line Transaction Processing.
It is a spread sheet software for spectrum users.
Optical Mark Recognition.
Database that can be used directly from a terminal by the user.
Refers to a computer wherein each machine instruction contains one address only. It may be either of the operand or of the storage location for the results.

A computer instruction that contains one address field. For example, an instruction to load the contents of location A. Syn: single-address instruction; single-operand instruction. Contrast with: multiaddress instruction; two-address instruction; three-address instruction; four-address instruction; zeroaddress instruction.

A method of implied addressing in which the operands for a computer instruction are understood to be in the storage locations following the locations of the operands used for the last instruction executed. Contrast with: repetitive addressing.
See: direct address.
Refers to any. unlikely to be repeated action.

A computer instruction that contains two address fields, the second containing the address of the instruction to be executed next. For example, an instruction to load the contents of location A, then execute the instruction at location B. Contrast with: two-plus-one address instruction; three-plus-one address instruction; four-plus-one address instruction.

(1) Refers to a system that uses a number of input/output terminals which can be geographically separated from the computer during the main processing by great distances. It also refers to the situation when a job is performed by a device under the control of CPU. (2) Pertaining to a system or mode of operation in which input data enter the computer directly from the point of origin or output data are transmitted directly to the point where they are used. For example, an airline reservation system. Contrast with: batch. See also: conversational; interactive; real time. (3) Pertaining to a device or process that is under the direct control of the central processing unit of a computer. Contrast with: off-line.
See: incremental compiler.
A computer system (with backup capabilities in case of system failure) with a real-time capability to record, store, control, retrieve, and reproduce computer programs, information, or data.
See: operation code.
Means to make a file available for reading or writing in a program.
Any computer whose technical information has entered the public domain.
The type of system wherein a computer will print a message in response to a feed back from a sensor or control equipment, on which a human operator is required to intervene

(1) A sub-routine that is inserted into a routine at each place it is used.(2) A subroutine that is copied into a computer program at each place that it is called. Syn: direct insert subroutine. Contrast with: closed subroutine. See also: inline code; macro.

(1) The object or "target" of some program operation. (2) A variable, constant, or function upon which an operation is to be performed. For example, in the expression A = B + 3, B and 3 are the operands.

(1) Refers to execution of any defined action.(2) In computer mathematics, the action specified by an operator on one or more operands. For example, in the expression A = B + 3, the process of adding B to 3 to obtain A. (3) In programming, a defined action that can be performed by a computer system; for example, addition, comparison , branching. Note: Unlike the mathematical meaning, such an operation may not involve an operator or operands; for example, the operation Halt. (4) The process of running a computer system in its intended environment to perform its intended functions.

The period of time in the software life cycle during which a software product is employed in its operational environment, monitored for satisfactory performance, and modified as necessary to correct problems or to respond to changing requirements.

(1) Refers to that portion of the instruction word which specifies the operation to be carried out by the instruction. (2) A character or set of characters that specifies a computer operation; for operation exception. An exception that occurs when a program encounters an invalid operation code. See also: addressing exception; data exception; overflow exception; pmtection exception; underflow exception.
The field of a computer instruction that specifies the operation to be performed. Syn: function field; operation part. Contrast with: address field.
Refers to the study of some human operation or set of operations by quantitative means.

(1) Pertaining to a system or component that is ready for use in its intended environment. (2) Pertaining to a system or component that is installed in its intended environment. (3) Pertaining to the environment in which a system or component is intended to be used.

A component in a database application that supports the maintenance of data associated with a major operational process. For example, in an order entry system, the maintenance of customer data and the entry of orders would be considered operational data areas. See support data area .
Testing conducted to evaluate a system or component in its operational environment. Contrast with: development testing. See also: acceptance testing; qualification testing.

The quantity of transactions per unit of time, for all users, in all operational data areas of a database application. This figure is commonly expressed as the number of transactions per day for all operational data areas, and is used to estimate server and network capacity requirements. See operational data area, simultaneous users, transaction .

(1) Refers to any person who operates a machine.(2) A mathematical or logical symbol that represents an action to be performed in an operation. For example, in the expression A = B + 3, + is the operator, representing addition. (3) A person who operates a computer system.
See: operation field.

A document that provides the information necessary to initiate and operate a system or component. Typically described are procedures for preparation, operation, monitoring, and recovery. Note: An operator manual is distinguished from a user manual when a distinction is made between those who operate a computer system (mounting tapes, etc.) and those who use the system for its intended purpose. See also: diagnostic manual; installation manual; programmer manual; support manual; user manual.
It is an optical input device to read hand writing, mark sensed papers and printed characters.
Refers to the disks that hold data digitally Such disks are used for storing computer data.

Refers to an electrical transmission cable made up of thread of highly transparent glass. It can carry very high frequency pulses at very high speed without any electromagnetic inference and attenuation of signal.

It is a printing font that can be accurately read by reading machines as also by people Optical Mark Reader (OMR): Refers to a reader that senses the minute block spots created by special pencils on a form and restores the data on a magnetic tape, disk or punched cards comparing the same with standard data
It is an optically sensing device that accepts a page of printed matter.
A pen like magnetically sensing device that can read bar codes and enters appropriate information into a computer.
Refers to a device that scan data optically and transmits the information received to a computer
It is a fast type reader It has a speed of 1000 cards per minute or 1000 characters per second.
It is a compiler that translates High-language program by removing [0, inefficiencies and inaccuracies.
A modifier key that is available on . some key boards.
It is logic gate that operates with binary digits With a two input OR-Gate the truth table is
In software design, a type of structure clash in which a program must deal with two or more data sets that have been sorted in different orders. See also: data structurecentered design.
Refers to the hierchical order in which computer takes up calculations.
A formally defined structure that takes resources from the environment and processes them to produce outputs.
The address of the initial storage location assigned to a computer program in main memory. See also: assembled origin; loaded origin. Contrast with: starting address.
A naturally occurring substance that is used as substrata in bubble memories.

(1) The program which supervises and controls an entire computer system including all of its periphera1s. It provides a link between the hardware and the applications package being run.(2) System software that manages and controls the activities of the computer. The operating system acts as the interface between applications and the computer hardware. (3) Software that controls the execution of a computer program and may provide scheduling, debugging, input-output control, accounting, compilation, storage assignment, data management, and related services. (4) A collection of software, firmware, and hardware elements that controls the execution of computer programs and provides such services as computer resource allocation, job control, input/output control, and file management in a computer system.
Open System Inter-connection.
A SQL Join operation in which all rows of the joined tables are returned, whether or not a match is made between columns.
A synonym for the primary query in a statement that includes a subquery. See subquery .

(1) Pertaining to data transmitted to an external destination. (2) Pertaining to a device, process, or channel involved in transmitting data to an external destination. (3) To transmit data to an external destination. (4) Loosely, output data. Contrast with: input. (4) It refers to the available work of computers work. May also be information produced during operation.
It is that pan of the main memory that is reserved for output data.

A logical expression specifying one or more conditions that program outputs must satisfy in order for the program to be correct. Contrast with: input assertion; loop assertion. See also: inductive assertion method.
It is the channel that connects peripheral units with the central processing unit for transferring the information output
Any device that is used to take out information from a computer and to present them in the desired form to the user e.g. digital plotter printer etc.
Refers to the basic elements that build up pictures on the screen.
Refers to overflow of data.
Means to destroy information in a memory location by writing a new information.
Refers to a numerical answer that is too big for a computer to store in the space allowed.

An exception that occurs when the result of an arithmetic operation exceeds the size of the storage location designated to receive it. See also: addressing exception; data exception; operation exception; protection exception; underflow excep tion.
See: housekeeping operation.

The amount of time a computer system spends performing tasks that do not contribute directly to the progress of any user task; for example, time spent tabulating computer resource usage for billing purposes.
Means to perform more than one function simultaneously.
It refers to the simultaneous execution of input, processing and output activities for different programs by a computer system

(1) Refers to a file-usually on desk that brings information into another program.(2) A storage allocation technique in which computer program segments are loaded from auxiliary storage to main storage when needed, overwriting other segments not currently in use. (3) A computer program segment that is maintained in auxiliary storage and loaded overlay supervisor. A routine that controls the sequencing and positioning of overlays.
To assign an operator, identifier, or literal more than one meaning, depending upon the data types associated with it at any given time during program execution.
It is a fabrication process that use an oxide to isolate one MOS device from another
A program counter register in which the location of the current instruction is kept.
Private Automatic Branch Exchange.

(1) Means combining of two or more items into one word for saving memory space. (2) To store data in a compact form in a storage medium, using known characteristics of the data and medium in such a way as to permit recovery of the data. Contrast with: unpack.

(1) Refers to a programme or a collection of programmes to be used by more than one business organization. (2) A separately compilable software component consisting of related data types, data objects, and subprograms. See also: data abstraction; encapsulation; information hiding.
Software that is available from hardware manufacturers or software houses 1n the form of prepared package made up of the program documents, test data etc.
In software development, the assignment of modules to segments to be handled as distinct physical units for execution by a computer.
It refers to an economical way of storing decimal digits represented as binary coded decimals (BCD) using only four bits per digit.

1. A unit of information transmitted as a whole from one device to another on a network. 2. In packet- switching networks, a transmission unit of fixed maxi- mum size that consists of binary digits representing both data and a header containing an identification number, source and destination addresses, and sometimes error- control data. See also packet switching.
It is an easy means of transmitting information from one place to another.

It is an economical way of sending long data over long distances. The data is sent from a sending to a receiving terminal or computer in packets of fixed length (1000 bits or so). Each packet is sent separately and may be interspersed with packet from another location.
Refers to the computer facilities that are responsible for "assembling" and "switching" packets of data in a packet switching process.
British Telecom's service which allows access via the telephone to various on-line services.

It is a measure of the quantity of data that can be held by a packing store.
It is the area of plated copper on a printed circuit board that provides a contact for soldering component leads.
Refers to a buffer character that is used to fill a blank.
(1) The technique of filling out a fixed-length block of data with dummy characters, words, or records. (2) Dummy characters, words, or records used to fill out a fixed-length block of data.
It is a hand-held input device. It is used for making a cursor move either up or down or right or left on screen. It can be achieved by turning a dial on the paddle.

(1) It refers to a full screen of data as displayed by a monitor. In some cases each full screen is called a frame and a page consists of serveral frames.(2) A fixed-length segment of data or of a computer program treated as a unit in storage allocation. See also: paging. (3) In a virtual storage system, a fixedlength segment of data or of a computer program that has a virtual address and is transferred as a unit between main and auxiliary storage. (4) A screenful of information on a video display terminal.
A portion of main storage that is unused when the last page of data or of a computer program does not fill the entire block of storage allocated to it. See also: paging.
A software of telling the printer how to construct a page from a combination of text, fonts and graphics.
Refers to an interruption in a program that takes place when an item of data or instruction. that is not in current memory is needed

(1) It is the buffer location in the memory that can store one page generally of 2 to 4 KB of commands or data. (2) A block of main storage having the size of, and used to hold, a page. See also: paging.
Refers to the process of swapping programs or data from disk storage to the computer's main storage.
ADTP software.
It is the process of swapping programs or data from the computer's main storage to disk storage
Printer wherein the whole page of characters is composed and determined within the device prior to printing e.g Laser Printer.
It refers to a piece of optical scanning equipment that scans many lines of information, with scanning pattern being determined by program control and or control symbol intermixed with input data.
Refers to a control character which if , pressed causes a printer to forget the rest of the current page and switchover to the top of the next page.
The exchange of pages between main storage and auxiliary storage. See also: paging.
A table that identifies the location of pages in storage and gives significant attributes of those pages. See also: paging.
See: paging (3).
In the paging method of storage allocation, the first page in a series of pages.
A routine that initiates and controls the transfer of pages between main and auxiliary storage. See also: paging.
It is an innovation of printing method by electronic manipulation of graphics for setting up an entire page It also refers to the process whereby pages are numbered.

(1) Refers to the technique to moving programs back and forth from real memory to virtual memory. (2) A storage allocation technique in which programs or data are divided into fixed-length blocks called pages, main storage is divided into blocks of the same length called page frames, and pages are stored in page frames, not necessarily contiguously or in logical order. Syn: block allocation. Contrast with: contiguous allocation. (3) A storage allocation technique in which programs or data are divided into fixedlength blocks called pages, main storage is divided into blocks of the same length called page frames, and pages are transferred between main and auxiliary storage as needed. See also: anticipatory paging; demand paging; virtual storage. (4) The transfer of pages as in (3). Syn: page turning. See also: page; page breakage; page frame; page swapping; page table; page zero; pager; working set.
It is the average rate at which pages i are transferred from main memory to a direct access storage device
Phase Alternation Line.
Plan Applier Mechanism.

It is an early form of data storage device. It is a continuous ribbon or paper into which a pattern of holes is punched The tape is divided into columns and each column is used to store one character.
It is an output device that converts data from a binary format in main storage to coded hole patterns punched into paper tape.
It is an input device that converts data punched into paper tape into a binary format for processing.
It is a machine that is used for ensuring that punching has been done accurately and the errors have not been allowed to enter the computer system.
Positive Acknowledgement and Retransmission.
Refers to a set of one or more COBOL sentences that make up a logical processing entity and proceeded by a paragraph header or name.
Word processing wherein a document is produced by assembling the data collected from paragraphs that are stored on the magnetic media like disks and tapes

(1 Pertaining to the simultaneous transfer, occurrence, or processing of the individual parts of a whole, such as the bits of a character, using separate facilities for the various parts. Contrast with: serial (1). (2) See: concurrent.
The process of obtaining of or storage of information into a storage where the time needed for .it depends on the simultaneous transfer of all element& of a word from a giver, storage location.
Refers to an adder that carries out its operation by bringing in all digits simultaneously from each of the quantities involved.
Carrying out the sum of a pair of multi-digit binary numbers by simultaneous operation of set of adjacent full adders.
An electric circuit where in the elements, branches or components are joined between two points with one of the two ends of each component joined to each other.

Refers to a computer wherein the addition is performed by simultaneously all the bits in one binary number to those of the same column of the another and then adding the resulting carries to form the sum.
It is the process whereby the data is changed to a new data processing system which involves running both the old and new systems simultaneously for a period of time.
It is a method used to transfer data between devices. In it all the bits or characters or bytes are presented to the interface simultaneously on separate conductors.
It is the circuit that provides a parallel socket for connecting external devices to a micro-computer, for both output and input of data.
Refers to the peliormance of several operations simultaneously through the provision of individual, similar or identical devices for each such operation.
Refers to the printer that receives information from the computer one character at a time through eight parallel circuits.
It is a system of sending a data in a computer. It generally refers to a method of communication between a computer and its printer.
It is a method of printing in which the whole row is printed at a time.
To carry out two or more tasks simultaneously in a computer.
Refers to reading of a data card one row at a time instead of a character at a time i.e. serial reading.
For this we need at least as many wires or paths as there are bits to be transmitted simultaneously. Such a happening occurs with in and between the IC in a computer.

(1) A value passed to an application to direct performance. For example, a query could be set up with a parameter that limits the returned records to those falling after a specific date. Changing the value of the parameter changes the returned selection of records. (2) Refers to a setting or a constant, within the program or system, that has a particular meaning. During course of carrying out the program the computer caries out different tasks which depend on the value of some thing or on the specific key that was last pressed.(3) A variable that is given a constant value for a specified application. See also: adaptation parameter. (4) A constant, variable, or expression that is used to pass values between software modules. See also: argument; formal parameter.
It refers to the technique whereby a line, a curve or suliace is defined by equations based on some independent variable.
Refers to a file whose contents are needed for creating a new file.
It is an error-checking system that ensures safe data transmission between computers and their devices.
An extra bit that is included with a set of binary digits as a check to see that all binary digits are transferred correctly They are of two types odd parity and even parity.
Automatic error detection technique wherein checking bits are also provided along with data bits.
Refers to an occurrence of an error when a unit of data is found to have inconsistent parity with the system.

To determine the syntactic structure of a language unit by decomposing it into more elementary subunits and establishing the relationships among the subunits. For example, to decompose blocks into statements, statements into expressions, expressions into operators and operands.
(1) Program that analyses and understands statements. (2) A software tool that parses computer programs or other text, often as the first step of assembly, compilation, interpretation, or analysis.
Refers to the process whereby the statement are broken into syntactic units.
In proof of correctness, a designation indicating that a program's output assertions follow logically from its input assertions and processing steps. Contrast with: total correctness.
Refers to an area of fixed size in main memory that can be divided into partitions in a multiprogramming environment each containing a varying number of bytes.
A number of logically related, sequential files, each of which is known as a member. They are stored together and identified by one data set name.
(1) Means sub-dividing a computer storage area in smaller units which are allocated to specific jobs or tasks. (2) (IEEE Std 830-1984 [SI) Decomposition; the separation of the whole into its parts.
Refers to a programmer who translates the physical explanation for matching a part into a series of mathematical steps and then codes computer instructions for those steps.
A high-level programming language developed in 1970's as a teaching language.
It was the first significant calculating machine.

(1) Means scanning of source by a compiler or assembler. (2) A single cycle in the processing of a set of data, usually performing part of an overall process. For example, a pass of an assembler through a source program; a pass of a sort program through a set of data.
It refers to a security measure on many operating systems. It is a code for authorized persons. It is used as a check when logging in.
(IEEE Std 829-1983 [51) Decision rules used to determine whether a software item or a software feature passes or fails a test. See also: test criteria.
It is the process whereby parameters are transferred between a main program and a sub-routine.
Means to place information previously "cut" from a document into new position.

(1) A modification made directly to an object program without reassembling or recompiling from the source program. (2) A modification made to a source program as a last-minute fix or afterthought. (3) Any modification to a source or object program. (4) To perform a modification as in (11, (21, or (3). (5) A quick change to an existing program so cause it to operate in a different way.
It is a make-shift technique used for modification error by changing the object code of the program.

(1) In software engineering, a sequence of instructions that may be performed in the execution of a computer program. (2) In file access, a hierarchical sequence of directory and subdirectory names specifying the storage location of a file. (3) Refers to the hierarchy of files through which control passes in search of a particular file.
Analysis of a computer program to identify all possible paths through the program, to detect incomplete paths, or to discover portions of the program that are not on any path.
A set of conditions that must be met in order for a particular program path to be executed.
A logical expression indicating the input conditions that must be met in order for a particular program path to be executed.
Testing designed to execute all or selected paths through a computer program. Contrast with: branch testing; statement testing.

A type of coupling in which one software module affects or depends upon the internal implementation of another. Contrast with: commonenvironment coupling; content coupling; control coupling; data coupling; hybrid coupling.
Refers to any computerized module that can distinguish among the members of a pre-determined set of abstract or realistic symbols.
See: data-sensitive fault.
To suspend the execution of a computer program. Syn: halt (2). Contrast with: h P *

A popular painting and drawing program for micro-computers.

(1) Physical Configuration Audit. Is an audit performed at the completion of the acceptance testing of the system. The primary intent of the audit is to verify that the system is ready for operation. A designator which indicates that an item is subject to approval by the Design Agency.
Software maintenance performed to improve the performance, maintainability, or other attributes of a computer program. Contrast with: adaptive maintenance; corrective maintenance.

Means execution of instructions in a computer.

(1) It is one of the major factors that determinces the total productivity of the system. (2) The degree to which a system or component accomplishes its designated functions within given constraints, such as speed, accuracy, or memory usage.
are efficiency, integrity, reliability, survivability, and usability.
Refers to a program that keeps a track of service levels that are being delivered by a computer system.
Characteristics governing how well the software functions.

A requirement that imposes conditions on a functional requirement; for example a requirement that specifies the speed, accuracy, or memory usage with which a given function must be performed. Contrast with: design requirement; functional requirement; implementation requirement; interface requirement; physical requirement.

A document that specifies the performance characteristics that a system or component must possess. These characteristics typically include speed, accuracy, and memory usage. Often part of a requirements specification.
Testing conducted to evaluate the compliance of a system or component with specified performance requirements. See also: functional testing.
Refers to the detachable perforated strips on the two sides of fanfold computer paper.
Any device that is connected to and controlled by a computer but external to CPU e.g. card reader, disk drive etc.
The input/output device and the auxiliary storage units in a data processing centre.
Empty slots built into the housing of some computers for fixing of printed circuits. cards to increase capabilities without any change in hardware design.
Refers to non-volatile but erasable memory like ROM

To make use of PC for various applications such as entertainment, home management, education etc.
A security number which a computer system needs before a user can access the system

It is a diagram that represents interdependence of work element and time.
A popular low-cost micro-computer.
Daisy wheel printer.

An abstract, formal model of information flow, showing static and dynamic properties of a system. A Petri net is usually represented as a graph having two types of nodes (called places and transitions) connected by arcs, and markings (called tokens) indicating dynamic properties.

Memory which makes use of optical method for storing information.

The unit of data for input/output e.g record on disk.

A requirement that specifies a physical characteristic that a system or system component must possess; for example, material, shape, size, weight. Contrast with: design requirement; functional requirement; implementation requirement; interface requirement; performance requirement.
Peripheral Interface Adapter.
Refers to an input device, like light pen, mouse, joy-stick etc. that is used on a display screen.

See also: critical design review; system design review. (2) A review as in (1) of any hardware or software component.

A person who acts as the primary point of contact and principal approver for the development community, and is the focal point for the development team. The PDR works directly with the PER to coordinate developer responses to requirements and issues generated by the end-user community. The PDR manages the entire lifecycle, either for a specific component or for the entire project, and is responsible for ensuring that appropriate technical experts conduct technical reviews in a timely manner. On large projects, multiple PDRs may exist, each dedicated to representing the development team for one or more components or subsystems. In this case, a lead PDR is assigned to coordinate activities with the lead PER.

A person who acts as the primary point of contact and principal approver for the end-user community. In essence, the PER acts as the focal point for the end user community. The PER works directly with the Primary Developer Representative to identify subject matter experts, coordinate meetings, conduct reviews, and track identified issues, consolidating and coordinating the responses of all end-users into a cohesive set of communications. On large projects, multiple PERs may exist, each dedicated to representing the end user community for one or more components or subsystems. In this case, a lead PER is assigned to coordinate activities with the lead PDR.
(1) A field or fields whose individual or combined values uniquely identify a record in a database. (2) A unique field for a record. It is used to sort records for processing.

A type of cohesion in which the tasks performed by a software module all contribute to a given program procedure, such as an iteration or decision process. Contrust with: coincidental cohesion; communicational cohesion; functional cohesion; logical cohesion; sequential cohesion; temporal cohesion.

Syn: procedure-oriented language. Contrast with: nonprocedural language. See also: algebraic language; algorithmic procedure. (1) A course of action to be taken to perform a given task. (2) A written description of a course of action as in (1); for example, a documented test procedure. (3) A portion of a computer program that is named and that performs a specific action.

(1) A unique, finite course of steps that leads to a particular result. In configuration management, the initial approved technical documentation (including, for software, the source code listing) defining a configuration item during the production, operation, maintenance, and logistic support of its life cycle. The current approved or conditionally approved technical documentation defining a configuration item during the production, operation, maintenance, and logistic support phases of its life cycle. A document that provides the information necessary to develop or modify software for a given computer system. An integrated collection of software tools accessed via a single command language to provide programming support capabilities throughout the software life cycle. The environment typically includes tools for specifying, designing, editing, compiling, loading, testing, configuration management, and project management. Sometimes called integrated programming support environment. See also: scaffolding.

A set of programming languages and the support software (editors, project file. A central repository of material pertinent to a project. Contents typically include memos, plans, technical reports, and related items. Syn: project notebook.

(1) A concerted effort that is focused on developing or maintaining a specific software product or system. A project has a fixed scope, structure, and delivery schedule. A file (manual or online) in which project documentation is stored.

A document that describes the technical and management approach to be followed for a project. For example, a software development plan.

A breakpoint that is initiated upon entry into a program or routine. Syn: preamble breakpoint. Contrast with: epilog breakpoint. See also: code breakpoint; data breakpoint; dynamic breakpoint; programmable breakpoint; static breakpoint.

A preliminary type, form, or instance of a system that serves as a model for later stages or for the final, complete version of the system.

(1) The process of building an experimental system quickly and inexpensively for demonstration and evaluation so that end-users can better determine the requirements of an application. For example, an instruction specifying the desired format of source code listings. Syn: pragma; pseudo-op; pseudo operation. (2) It is a system of symbols that is used for representing various elements of programming the micro-processor. (3) A combination of programming language constructs and natural language used to define an algorithm or business rule. Pseudocode is often used as a communications bridge between end-users and analysts or programmers.

A defined, planned series of assessment activities performed on hardware, technologies, software or firmware, acceptance equipment hardware and software, and weapon test programs. The QE encompasses evaluations previously referred to as TMS, QS, EQ, and TPV. [see also engineering evaluation release (EER) and qualification evaluation release (QER)]
A document used to summarize the results of a qualification evaluation (QE), to assign a QE status to the item, and to authorize use of the item for a specific application.
A group of persons responsible for implementing Qualification Evaluations.
Testing conducted to determine whether a system or component is suitable for operational use. See also: acceptance testing; development testing; operational testing.
(1) Satisfaction of customer criteria; conformance to design specifications.(2) The degree to which a system, component, or process meets specified requirements.
A system of procedures carried out to ensure that a product or a system adheres or conforms to established standards. Also called: quality control.

(1) A planned and systematic pattern of all actions necessary to provide adequate confidence that an item or product conforms to established technical requirements. (2) A set of activities designed to evaluate the process by which products are developed or manufactured. Contrast with: quality control (1).

The assessment of a deliverable for the presence of required internal and supporting elements. Generally performed by a Quality Assurance Reviewer who is not a member of the development team or end user base. See Assessment .

A feature or characteristic that affects an item's quality. Syn: quality factor. Note: In a hierarchy of quality attributes, higher level attributes may be called quality factors, lower level attributes called quality attributes.

Note: This term has no standardized meaning in software engineering at this time. Candidate definitions are: (1) A set of activities designed to evaluate the quality of developed or manufactured products. Contrast with: quality assurance (2). (2) The process of verifying one's own work or that of a co-worker. (3) Synonym for quality assurance.

(also referred to as quality records) Information which indicates the extent of conformance to requirements and control over processes. This information is based on process control data, inspection and acceptance activities, or traceability records.

(1) See: quality attribute. Note: In a hierarchy of quality attributes, higher level attributes may be called quality factors, lower level attributes called quality attributes. (1) Refers to a language that is particularly designed to assist the user to interrogate a particular database. (2) A language used to access information stored in a database. Contrast with: programming language; specification language.

A multi-element data structure from which (by strict definition) elements can be removed only in the same order in which they were inserted; that is, it follows a first in, first out (FIFO) constraint. There are also several types of queues in which removal is based on factors other than order of insertion for example, some priority value assigned to each element. See also deque, element (defini- tion 1). Compare stack.

(1) It is a list or line of data, where new items are added at one end and the items are taken from other end. (2) A list in which items are appended to the last position of the list and retrieved from the first position of the list. Contrast with: character type; enumeration type; integer type; logical type.
Refers to any data access method wherein the transfer of data between main memory and input output device is automatically regulated synchronously.
In networking, the process of buffering data in preparation for transmission. See also fair queuing; first in, first out; last in, first out; weighted fair queuing.
It is a type of plug in electrical socket that permits rapid locking and unlocking of the making connector halves.
An expert system that serves as an electronic text book, a low level consultant and a diagnostic consultant

An efficient sort algorithm, described by C.A.R. Hoare in 1962, in which the essential strategy is to divide and conquer. A quicksort begins by scanning the list to be sorted for a median value. This value, called the pivot, is then moved to its final position in the list. Next, all items in the list whose values are less than the pivot value are moved to one side of the list, and the items with values greater than the pivot value are moved to the other side. Each resulting side is sorted the same way, until a fully sorted list results. See also sort algorithm. Compare bubble sort, insertion sort, merge sort.
The process of bringing a device or system to a halt by rejecting new requests for work.
Quad-in-line package. It has four columns of pins on the IC package. As opposed to a dual line packed with two rows.
The key board on a normal two-handed typewriter. It has been derived from the first six keys on the second row of the key board.

Refers to indefinite state that results when two computer instructions are operating concurrently and it is not possible to guess which of them will finish first.

Refers to a symbol that is used to separate an integral part from fractional part of a number expressed in a radix notation.
It is a process of sorting algorithm wherein the file is first sorted on the least significant digit of the sort key, then the next and so on.

Acronym for random access memory. Semicon- ductor-based memory that can be read and written by the central processing unit (CPU) or other hardware devices. The storage locations can be accessed in any order. Note that the various types of ROM memory are capable of ran- dom access but cannot be written to. The term RAM, how- ever, is generally understood to refer to volatile memory that can be written to as well as read. Compare core, EPROM, flash memory, PROM, ROM (definition 2).
Random Access Memory.
Refers to those files that permits the operating system to find out the exact position of any record instantly.
It is a peripheral (e.g. magnetic disk) that can be read in a different order from that in which it was written.
A failure whose occurrence is unpredictable except in a probabilistic or statistical sense. See also: intermittent fault; transient error.

(1) To detect and interpret data from another source generally a disk drive, storage system etc. (2) To access data from a storage device or data medium. See also: destructive read; nondestructive read. Contrast with: write.

(1) Pertaining to the processing of data by a computer in connection with another process outside of the computer according to time requirements imposed by the outside process. Examples of real-time software include test equipment and weapon component software or firmware. (2) Pertaining to a system or mode of operation in which computation is performed during the actual time that an external process occurs, in order that the computation results can be used to control, monitor, or respond in a timely manner to the external process. Contrast with: batch. See also: conversational; interactive; interrupt; on-line. (3) Refers to the type of operation of computer wherein the computer is interacting with events in the world of people, rather than of circuit.
It is a device that can only receive data.
The characteristics of the computing system which provide for continuity of system operation when one or more processors, storage units, or communication links fails.

(1) A group of related fields. A single row of a relational database table that contains each field defined for the table. (2) Refers to each entry in a database. Each record consists of entries in a number of fields and the collection of records forms a file. (3) A set of related data items treated as a unit. For example, in stock control, the data for each invoice could constitute one record.

(1) A process in which a software module calls itself. See also: simultaneous recursion. (2) The process of defining or generating a process or data structure in terms of itself.

(1) Structured retesting of a software component or application to verify that any modifications made have not caused unintended effects and that the software still complies with its specified requirements. (2) Testing to verify that a modified software system or unit continues to meet its specified requirements without performance degradation or failure resulting from the implementation of the modification(s). (3) Selective retesting of a system or component to verify that modifications have not caused unintended effects and that the system or component still complies with its specified requirements.

In database management, a non- procedural method for manipulating relations (tables). There are two families of relational calculus: domain cal- culus and tuple calculus. The two families of relational calculus are mathematically equivalent to each other and to relational algebra. Using either family, one can formu- late a description of a desired relation, based on the exist- ing relations in the database.
See RDBMS.

A database or database manage- ment system that stores information in tables rows and columns of data and conducts searches by using data in specified columns of one table to find additional data in another table. In a relational database, the rows of a table represent records (collections of information about sepa- rate items) and the columns represent fields (particular attributes of a record). In conducting searches, a relational database matches information from a field in one table with information in a corresponding field of another table to produce a third table that combines requested data from both tables. For example, if one table contains the fields EMPLOYEE-ID, LAST-NAME, FIRST-NAME, and HIRE-DATE, and another contains the fields DEPT, EMPLOYEE-ID, and SALARY, a relational database can match the EMPLOYEE-ID fields in the two tables to find such information as the names of all employees earning a certain salary or the departments of all employees hired after a certain date. In other words, a relational database uses matching values in two tables to relate information in one to information in the other. Microcomputer database products typically are relational databases. Compare flat- file database, inverted-list database.

An RDBMS is a database management application that can create, organize, and store data. The RDBMS treats data as if they were stored in two-dimensional tables. It can relate data stored in one table to data in another as long as the two tables share a common data element, or key. See primary key, foreign key .

An operator that allows the pro- grammer to compare two (or more) values or expressions. Typical relational operators are greater than (>), equal to (=), less than (<), not equal to (<>), greater than or equal to (>=), and less than or equal to (<=). See also relational expression.

An address that must be adjusted by the addition of an offset to determine the address of the storage location to be accessed. Contrast with: absolute address. See also: base address; indexed address; self-relative address.
See: relocating loader.
A software application or component that has been tested and found to be in compliance with design documentation, and placed into production. See production.

(1) The ability of a software application or component to perform its required functions under design-compliant conditions for a specified period of time. (2) The probability of failure-free operation of the software for a specified time, in a specified environment. (3) If refers to .the ability of a computer system to carry out its functions for a given period of time. (4) The ability of a system or component to perform its required functions under stated conditions for a specified period of time. See also: availability; MTBF.
The improvement in reliability that results from correction of faults.

Pertaining to code that can be loaded into any part of main memory. The starting address is established by the loader, which then adjusts the addresses in the code to reflect the storage locations into which the code has been loaded. See also: relocating loader.
An address that is to be adjusted by the loader when the computer program containing the address is loaded into memory. Contrast with: absolute address.
Code containing addresses that are to be adjusted by the loader to reflect the storage locations into which the code is loaded. Contrast with: absolute code.

To move machine code from one portion of main memory to another and to adjust the addresses so that the code can be executed in its new location.
An assembler that produces relocatable code. Contrast with: absolute assembler.

A loader that reads relocatable code into main memory and adjusts the addresses in the code to reflect the storage locations into which the code has been loaded. Syn: relative loader. Contrast with: absolute loader.
The part of an object module or load module that identifies the addresses that must be adjusted when a relocation occurs.

(1) A condition or capability needed by a user to solve a problem or achieve an objective. (2) A condition or capability that must be met or possessed by a system or system component to satisfy a contract, standard, specification, or other formally imposed documents. (3) A documented representation of a condition or capability as in (1) or (2). See also: design requirement; functional requirement; implementation requirement; interface requirement; performance requirement; physical requirement.
It follows the feasibility study in the development of a new application package but proceeds the design, implementation and review stages.
(IEEE Std 1002-1987 [91) A standard that describes the characteristics of a requirements specification.

(1) The process of studying user needs to arrive at a definition of system, hardware, or software requirements. (2) The process of studying and refining system, hardware, or software requirements. microinstruction depends on the value in an auxiliary register. Contrast with: bit steering. The period of time in the software life cycle during which the requirements for a software product are defined and documented.

A process or meeting during which the requirements for a system, hardware item, or software item are presented to project personnel, managers, users, customers, or other interested parties for comment or approval. Types include system requirements review, software requirements review. Contrast with: code review; design review; formal qualification review; test readiness review.

(1) A deliverable that specifies the manual and automated requirements for a software product in non-technical language that the customer and end-users can understand. The requirements specification focuses on what functions the application is to perform, not how those functions will be executed. (2) A document that specifies the requirements for a system or component. Typically included are functional requirements, performance requirements, interface requirements, design requirements, and development standards. Contrast with: design description. See also: functional specification; performance specification.
A specification language with special constructs and, sometimes, verification protocols, used to develop, analyze, and document hardware or software requirements. See also: design language.

A stage in the software lifecycle that immediately follows the planning stage. During this stage, the requirements for a software product are defined and documented. The output of this stage is a Requirements Specification.

A process that acts as a bridge between the different stages of the software development lifecycle, and provides an auditable trail to verify that each requirement is fulfilled and tested. For example, the design elements in a design document must be traceable to parent requirements in the predecessor requirements document as well as to child elements in subsidiary documents, such as the test plan and implementation document. Traceability may be implemented as a table or spreadsheet describing the relationships between application requirements, functional elements, design elements, implementation elements, and test cases. In this case, the table is termed the Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM). Traceability may also be implemented as an automated process that directly examines the related documents and reports valid traceability or errors in traceability.
To run a program again with the original data starting from the beginning.

(1) Refers to a word that has a specific meaning to the compiler or the operating system and thus it must not be used by the programmer when programming in the high-level. (2) A word in a programming language whose meaning is fixed by the rules of that language and which, in certain or all contexts, cannot be used by the programmer for any purpose other than its intended one. Examples include IF, THEN, WHILE.

Literally, without stroke; describes any typeface in which the characters have no serifs (the short lines or ornaments at the upper and lower ends of the strokes). A sans serif typeface usually possesses a more straightforward, geometric appearance than a typeface with serifs and typically lacks the contrast between thick and thin strokes found in serif faces. Sans serif typefaces are used more frequently in display type, such as head- lines, than in blocks of text. Compare serif 1 .
