A SQL Join operation used to compare values within the columns of one table. Self-joins join a table with itself, requiring that the table be assigned two different names, one of which must be an alias.
It is the code that makes an explicit attempt at each predetermined stage to determine its own correctness and then proceed further.
The degree to which a system or component contains enough information to explain its objectives and properties. See also: maintainability; testability; usability.
Pertaining to source code that contains comments explaining its objectives, operation, and other information useful in understanding and maintaining the code.

An address that must be added to the address of the instruction in which it appears to obtain the address of the storage location to be accessed. See also: base address; indexed address; offset; relative address.
Scanning Electron Microscope.
In natural language analysis is one that interprets a sentence in accordance with its meaning and not its form.
An error resulting from a misunderstanding of the relationship of symbols or groups of symbols to their meanings in a given language. Contrast with: syntactic error.
It refers to the disparity that exists between the binary machine language understood by a computer and high level language used for programming.
The relationships of symbols or groups of symbols to their meanings in a given language. Contrast with: syntax.
A shared variable used to synchronize concurrent processes by indicating whether an action has been completed or an event has occurred. See also:flag; indicator.
It is also known as solid state memory. It refers to any of the cheap compact memory device. It is generally produced in IC form.
A material that is neither a good conductor of electricity like copper nor a good insulator like plastic. It is some where between the two e.g. silicon.
It is a device used for sensing very low footages and amplifying them to some high voltage level.
It refers to the degree of response of a control unit to a change in the incoming signal.
An input device that measures values and provides digital readings for a computer system
Refers to the arrangement of items in accordance with a specified set of rules.

(1) Means that the records, files etc. are in a definite order and may only be manipulated on that basis. (2) Pertaining to the occurrence of two or more events or activities in such a manner that one must finish before the next begins. Syn: serial (2). See also: consecutive.

In a directory, the information for each record in a storage system is contained at the end of the previous record. The records may be accessed sequentially according to a sequence of record keys, which may not be contiguous with the records on the storage media-records.

A type of cohesion in which the output of one task performed by a software module serves as input to another task performed by the module. Contrast with: coincidental cohesion; communicational cohesion; functional cohesion; logical cohesion; procedural cohesion; temporal cohesion.
See: serial construct.
Refers to a file that has been organized sequentially.
Updating or listing records in a master file on the basis of a predetermined sequence of keys rather than in the order in which they are stored on the storage media.
It is a method of search wherein record key of an ordered file is compared to the desired key till a match is found.
A storage device, like a magnetic tape, that provides sequential access to the data stored on it

(1) Pertaining to the sequential transfer, occurrence, or processing of the individual parts of a whole, such as the bits of a character, using the same facilities for successive parts. Contrast with: parallel (1). (2) See: sequential.Means to handle the data in the same order as it is physically or geometrically arranged. (3)
Refers to a medium wherein data can be accessed in the same order as physically recorded.
A program construct consisting of a sequence of steps not involving a decision or loop. Syn: sequential construct.
Refers to a class of digital device that accepts serial sequential n-bit data streams and converts them into parallel n-bit words.
Refers to a shift register that can not be loaded in parallel and can not be read in parallel. In it the data can enter or leave only serially.
It is a method of communicating data between devices.
Refers to the circuit that provides connection to a socket that transmits or receives each bit of data in order, one after the order.
Input/output port in computer through which data are transmitted and received on bit at a time.
A printer which prints one character at a time as opposed to a line printer which prints one line at a time.

(1) Marked by the use of serifs. For example, Goudy is a serif typeface, whereas Helvetica is a sans serif typeface. See the illustration. Compare sans serif. (2) Any of the short lines or ornaments at the ends of the strokes that form a typeface character.
A mode, on logical area network, that provides service to the terminals on the network through managing on expensive shared resources.

On a local area network (LAN), a computer running administrative software that controls access to the network and its resources, such as printers and disk drives, and provides resources to computers functioning as work- stations on the network. 2. On the Internet or other net- work, a computer or program that responds to commands from a client. For example, a file server may contain an archive of data or program files; when a client submits a request for a file, the server transfers a copy of the file to the client. See also application server (definitions 1 and 2), client/server architecture. Compare client (definition 3).
A program that is shared over a network. The program is stored on the network server and can be used at more than one client machine at a time.
It is an educational software package for use of spectrum home computer.
Refers to a component whose mechanical movement is controlled by feedback of its position to a controller.
Refers to a collection of related entries.
The arrangement of data or devices for solving a given problem.
The period of time during which a system or component is being prepared for a specific operation. See also: busy time; down time; idle time; up time.
See: criticality.
Printing of a bold character by backing up the print head to, with in 1/100th of an inch, of its previous position and restraining.
Refers to the files held in the memory of one computer which can be read, used and altered by other computers to which it is linked either in a network or by telecommunications.
The use of the same portion of memory by two distinct persons or the memory so shared.

It is a paper feeding device that is attached with the printer. It is designed to automatically insert and line up single sheets of paper of envelops in the same way as an operator would carry out the task.
A computer program or routine that provides an interface between the user and a computer system or program.
It is an operation whereby each bit in a register moves one or more positions to the right or left.
It is the process of simultaneously clicking the mouse button while depressing the shift key on the key board.
Refers to an assembly language instruction designating that a shift is to be carried out on the contents of the register.
Refers to the location in the computer that is used only for shifting data to the left or right.
Any change of state caused by a subrou- tine, such as a routine that reads a value from a file and advances the current file position.
Means sorting and extracting certain desired items of information from a large amount of data.
Refers to the bit that signifies whether a binary number is negative or positive.
It is the left most position in a word. It is used to indicate whether a number is negative or positive.
Refers to the process of logging to a time sharing computer network.
It refers to an electrical pulse in an electronic circuit for the generation of information in the form of binary digit& represented by pulses (signals) and no pulses (no signals).
Means filtering a continuous signal.
Refers to that pol1ion of a digital signal which can be distinguished from other pol1ions of the signal either by its duration or by its position.
Refers to the processing of signals with the help of hard-wired or programmable devices.
It is a pin on an interface for a modem indicating if there is a probability of some error having occurred in the data and received by the modem.
It is a material that is used to manufacture semi-conductor devices.
A buffering technique in which a buffer is allocated to a computer program for the duration of the program's execution. Contrast with: dynamic buffering.
Data transferred in one direction only.
The degree to which a system or component has a design and implementation that is straightforward and easy to understand. Contrast with: complexity.
A high level language for programming simulation applications in real time applications.

(1) A model that behaves or operates like a given system when provided a set of controlled inputs. See also: emulation. (2). The process of developing or using a model as in (1). (3) The representation of a situation by a computer system that permits the user's decisions and actions to cause the same effects and results as if being performed for real.

(1) Refers to photo device, computer program or system that represents cel1ain features of the behavior of a physical or abstract system electronically. (2) A device, computer program, or system that behaves or operates like a given system when provided a set of controlled inputs. See also: emulator. (3) Refers to those systems which designed' to initiate a system for studying behavior.
Pertaining to the occurrence of two or more events at the same instant of time. Contrast with: concurrent.
A situation in which two software modules call each other.
A quantity of users and/or external systems connected to a multiuser database application for the purpose of exchanging and/or maintaining data.
Refers to the use of one word to store an item of data when the number of bits the word is sufficient for maintaining a specified precision
Refers to the process of work through a program by hand, step by step.
See: one-address instruction.
A microprogramming technique in which different microoperations are encoded as different values in the same field of a microinstruction. Contrast with: two-level encoding.
See: one-address instruction.
Diskette with only one side used for reading and writing information.
See: single-step opemtion.
A debugging technique in which a single computer instruction, or part of an instruction, is executed in response to an external signal. Syn: singlestep execution; stepby-step operation.
Refers to computer technology that is based on neutral networks which are designed to work in a similar manner as the human brain.
The process of estimating the amount of computer storage or the number of source lines required for a software system or component. Contrast with: timing.
Means to pass over one or more instruction in a sequence, without executing them when certain conditions are met.
An access method for use with a sequential or an indexed file.
A software game package for use on spectrum computer.
Any device that is operating under t control of another device.
See: problem state.
Refers to the protective envelope that used for storing a diskette.
Refers to the speed at which numerical controlled machine tools move from one position another
Means to move paper through printer.
Refers to the thin substrate that is obtained when a silicon ingot is cut i.e. the wafer.
It is a hand operated computing device. It consists of a ruler having a sliding centre section.
Super Large Scale-integration.
Solid Logic Technique.
IC circuits with less than 100 transistors on a single chip.
Refers to language and software system designed to make computer use as easy as possible for the layman.
Refers to a computer terminal that can I perform some local processing tasks instead of just being able to send and receive information from its host.
It is a plastic card that is similar to a credit card. It has a silicon chip embedded in it. It can store 64 kilobytes of data and instructions.
Means to destroy some area of storage by overwriting with another program.
Society for Management Information Systems.
Refers to the ability to scroll text without jerking it from one line to next.
System Network Architecture.
It is a list of variables and their current values that is periodically produced during the execution of a program and that can be used for debugging purposes.
A dynamic dump of the contents of one or more specified storage areas. See also: change dump; dynamic dump; memory dump; postmortem dump; selective dump; static dump.
The female partner in Ii connection between a cable and a computer port.
Refers to a temporary error condition from which recovery is possible. See: transient error.
A failure that permits continued operation of a system with partial operational capability. Contrast with: hard failure.
Refers to function keys on computer key board which can be programmed to return a given character to the computer.
The way in which tile length of a sector is fixed on a floppy disk, the length being set by the micro-computer when the disk is formatted.
It is the information stored on the disk or other magnetic media.

(1) Refers to the computer program produced and sold in the market generally with documentation, learning material, sample files etc. (2) Computer programs, procedures, and possibly associated documentation and data pertaining to the operation of a computer system. See also: application software; support software; system software. Contrast with: hardware.
Computer programs, procedures, and associated documentation pertaining to the operation of an application. The detailed instructions that control the operation of a computer system.
Set of software available for a particular computer system.
All changes to software (documentation and/or code) that result in software being different from the original release or previously changed copy.
A change, which has not yet been implemented, to existing code, its documentation, or its interfaces which would alter the approved baseline software which is under software configuration control.

(IEEE Std 1008-1987 [lo]) An inherent, possibly accidental, trait, quality, or property of software (for example, functionality, performance, attributes, design constraints, number of states, lines or branches).
Refers to the ability to use program written for one system on another system with minor or no change.
See: configuration management.
A unique alpha/numeric designator assigned to provide identification and traceability for software. This includes reference to change indicators such as version, revision, or suffix.
The definition of software architecture, components, modules, interfaces, testing approach, and necessary test and operational data for software to satisfy specified requirements.

(1) (IEEE Std 1012-1986 [121) A representation of software created to facilitate analysis, planning, implementation, and decision making. The software design description is used as a medium for communicating software design information, and may be thought of as a blueprint or model of the sy s tem. (2) (IEEE Std 1016-1987 [131) A representation of a software system created to facilitate analysis, planning, implementation, and decision making. A blueprint of model of the software system. The SDD is used as the primary medium for communicating software design information.
A document that defines the storage mechanisms, interfaces, internal processes, and outputs of a software application.
The engineering process that results in software, encompassing the span of time from initiation of the contracted effort through delivery to and acceptance by the requester.

A collection of material pertinent to the development of a given software unit or set of related units. Contents typically include the requirements, design, technical reports, code listings, test plans, test results, problem reports, schedules, and notes for the units. Syn: software development folder; software development notebook unit development folder.
See: software development file.

(1) A controlled collection of software, documentation, and associated tools and procedures used to facilitate the orderly development and subsequent support of software. A software development library provides storage of and controlled access to software and documentation in both human-readable and machine-readable form. The library may also contain management data pertinent to the software development project. (2) A software library containing computer readable and human readable information relevant to a software development effort. Syn: project library; program support library. Contrast with: master library; production library; software repository; system library.

A set of software development activities or stages that function together to guide the development and maintenance of a software product. The generally accepted stages for software development are Planning, Requirements, Design, Development, Integration and Test, Installation and Acceptance, and Maintenance. Each stage is finite in scope, requires a specific set of inputs, and produces a specific set of deliverables. The document that describes the SDLC may be called the SDLC Description or the Verification and Validation Plan (VVP).
See: software development file.
A project plan for a software development project.

The process by which user needs are translated into a software product. The process involves translating user needs into software requirements, transforming the software requirements into design, implementing the design in code, testing the code, and sometimes, installing and checking out the software for operational use. Note: These activities may overlap or be performed iteratively. See also: incremental development; rapid prototyping; spiral model; waterfall model.
The overall task of producing software. This may encompass internal design, external procurement, or both.

A software development technique in which two or more functionally identical variants of a program are developed from the same specification by different programmers or programming teams with the intent of providing error detection, increased reliability, additional documentation, or reduced probability that programming or compiler errors will influence the end results. See also: diversity.
Refers to the systems that enable one machine to run programs originally written for another without any rewriting being involved.
Method of encoding or decoding of computerized message by using programming technique rather than special hardware devices.

(1) The application of a systematic, disciplined, quantifiable approach to the development, operation, and maintenance of software; that is, the application of engineering to software. (2) The study of approaches as in (1). (3) The systematic approach to the specification, design, development, testing, operation, maintenance, and retirement of software.

The hardware, software, and firmware used to perform a software engineering effort. Typical elements include computer equipment, compilers, assemblers, operating systems, debuggers, simulators, emulators, test tools, documentation tools, and database management systems.

(1) (IEEE Std 829-1983 [51) A distinguishing characteristic of a software item (for example, performance, portability, or functionality). (2) (IEEE Std 1008-1987 [lo]) A software characteristic specified or implied by requirements documentation (for example, functionality, performance, attributes, or design constraints).
The breakdown of software into components/elements. Examples include modules, units, programs and subprograms.
(IEEE Std 829-1983 [51) Source code, object code, job control code, control data, or a collection of these items.
Controlled access storage areas that contain software code in development, test, or production mode.

A controlled collection of software quality metic. See: quality metric. software and related documentation designed to aid in software development, use, or maintenance. Types include master library, production library, software development library, software repository, system library. Syn: program library.
An individual designated by management to control access to master copies of software programs.

The period of time that begins when a software product is conceived and ends when the software is no longer available for use. The software life cycle typically includes a concept phase, requirements phase, design phase, implementation phase, test phase, installation and checkout phase, operation and maintenance phase, and, sometimes, retirement phase. Note: These phases may overlap or be performed iteratively. Contrast with: software development cycle.
That body of methods, rules, and procedures employed to accomplish the individual steps needed to properly manage maintenance.
Individual/Organizations responsible for software/hardware maintenance and for configuration control of an installed programmable system.
The medium(s) upon which the software resides. Software medium(s) include punched tape, magnetic tape, magnetic fixed disk, floppy disks, PROMS, EPROMS, etc.

(1) A qualitative measure of the processes used to produce software, or of a specific software product. (2) Objective assessments (in the form of quantified measurements) of a software application or component.

(1) Refers to a program that collects measurements on the internal operation of a computer so as to provide information on the causes and effects of events by relating the collected measurements to the program that is being executed at the time. (2) A software tool that executes concurrently with another program and provides detailed information about the execution of the other program. See also: hardware monitor; monitor.
It is a set of pre-written programs and can be purchased for use with a specified computer. Such a package can carry out various duties like accounting, pay roll etc.
Unauthorized copying of commercial or proprietary software.

A collective term used to describe the procedures and standards for software project management, software engineering, software test, software qualification evaluation, software configuration management, and software quality assurance.
A record of a software deficiency, such as a failure or an error in documentation.
(1) The complete set of computer programs, procedures, and possibly associated documentation and data designated for delivery to a user. (2) Any of the individual items in (1).
The rarest artifact in the software development universe. See project plan .

(1) The totality of features and characteristics of a software product that bear on its ability to satisfy the requirements specification. (2) The degree to which the software conforms to customer requirements and expectations.
A planned and systematic pattern of all actions necessary to provide adequate confidence that a software product conforms to established technical requirements.

A process designed to provide management with appropriate visibility into the software engineering processes being used by the project team. A formal process for evaluating the work products produced during the software development lifecycle.
A plan written at the software project level which states specific software quality assurance activities to be implemented on the project.
Those quality assurance actions that provide a means to control and measure the characteristics of software to established requirements.
A software library providing permanent, archival storage for software and related documentation. Contrast with: master library; production library; software development library; system library.

Also referred to as a Requirements Document (RD), or Software Requirements Specification (SRS). The SRS is a document (or set of related documents) that specifies the desired functionality for a software product through a series of requirements statements. The requirements statements are written in non-technical language that the customer and end-users can understand. The requirements specification focuses on what functions the application is to perform, not how those functions will be implemented.

(1) A review of the requirements specified for one or more software configuration items to evaluate their responsiveness to and interpretation of the system requirements and to determine whether they form a satisfactory basis for proceeding into preliminary design of the configuration items. See also: system requirements review. Note: This review is called software specification review by the US. Department of Defense. (2) A review as in (1) for any software component. (3) A review conducted to evaluate the completeness and adequacy of the requirements defined for a istrative resources to plan, organize, and control engineering functions. system; to evaluate the system engineering process that produced those requirements; to assess the results of system engineering studies; and to evaluate system engineering plans. See also: software requirements review.

(1) (IEEE Std 1012-1986 [121) Documentation of the essential requirements (functions, performance, design constraints, and attributes) of the software and its external interfaces. (2) Software requirements specification Stand-Alone Tool - A software tool that provides a single development or maintenance capability in one system.
See: software requirements review.
(IEEE Std 1008-1987 [loll Any event occurring during the execution of a software test that requires investigation.

A computer program used in the development, testing, analysis, or maintenance of a program or its documentation. Examples include comparator, cross-reference generator, decompiler, driver, editor, flowcharter, monitor, test case generator, timing analyzer.
Start of Heading.
See: maintenance (1).
It is also known as volumetric modeling and geometric modeling. It is the most realistic form of CAD representation.
Start of Message.
Standard Operating Procedure.
To arrange items in a predefined sequence.
Number of steps that are needed for bringing in order a disordered list.
Refers to the specified field in a record that is used to sort the records of a file.
It is a program that generates a sort program for production running.
The machine that tests each diagram on a wafer and marks the reject with a drop of ink
A device that arranges a set of records in a desired sequence.
Silicon on Sapphire.
It is a special electronic circuit, some times inside and a part of micro-computer. It can produce sound and can imitate various musical instruments.
Refers to data in raw form but converted into recognized set of characters.
The address of a device or storage location from which data is to be transferred. Contrast with: destination address.

(1) Software programming instructions written in a language readable by humans that must be translated into machine language before it can be executed by the computer. (2) Computer instructions and data definitions expressed in a form suitable for input to an assembler, compiler, or other translator. Note: A source program is made up of source code. Contrast with: object code.
See: Code generator (2).
A computer program written if a high-level or in assembly language.
It is the form on which data is written and from which it is keyed into a terminal or onto a punch card

(1) The high-level language e.g. COBOL. FORTRON etc. (2) The language in which the input to a machine-aided translation process is represented. For example, the language used to write a computer program. Contrast with: target language.
A computer program that must be compiled, assembled, or otherwise translated in order to be executed by a computer. Contrast with: object program.
Refers to the register that temporarily stores a data word during transit to memory.
Stack Pointer.
Systems and Procedures Association.
Refers to one or more blank characters.
Characters other than alphabetic and numeric characters that form a part of a character set.
See: absolute address.
See: absolute code.
Documentation that describes software requirements, designs, or other characteristics in a complete, precise, and verifiable manner.

A document that specifies, in a complete, precise, verifiable manner, the requirements, design, behavior, or other characteristics of a system or component, and, often, the procedures for determining whether these provisions have been satisfied. See also: formal specification; product specification; requirements specification.
A document used in configuration management to propose, transmit, and record changes to a specification. See also: configuration control; engineering change; notice of revision.

A language, often a machine-processible combination of natural and formal language, used to express the requirements, design, behavior, or other characteristics of a system or component. For example, a design language or requirements specification language. Contrast with: programming language; query language.
A diagram that depicts all of the specifications for a given system and shows their relationships to one another. See also: documentation tree.
Means the interpretation by the computer of the spoken word. Human voices can be digitally' recorded.

Refers to the production of speech sounds in a computer with the help of analog circuits that respond to digital instructions for production of all the standard phonemes of a language, which are programmed in ROM's.
The generation of speech by solid state circuits, used in hand held machines and educational toys where only a limited vocabulary is required.
With the help of this facility it is possible to check a document for wrongly spelt words.
Momentary surge in current on a mains line. It can have traumatic consequence for a delicate computer.
High quality 1mpact computer printer. It has spinning thimbles.

A development model that specifies the development and refinement of a series of successively more complex prototypes, followed by a traditional waterfall development model to place the application into production. See Waterfall development model .

A model of the software development process in which the constituent activities, typically requirements analysis, spool. To read input data, or write output data, to auxiliary or main storage for later processing or output, in order to permit inpuffoutput devices to operate concurrently with job execution. Derived from the acronym SPOOL for Simultaneous Peripheral Output On Line.
To join two segments of a paper tape with the help of a special device in such a way that the completed tape can be fed into a paper-tape of reader.
A visual display screen in which top and bottom areas of the screen face may be treated separate screws for data manipulation purpose.
Reel of magnetic tape.
Simultaneous Peripheral Operation on line". It is used to overcome the problem of slow peripheral devices holding up the execution of a program.
A program that initiates and controls spooling.
To use the storage system as a buffer when data is being sent to a peripheral.
Refers to anyone of various programs which arrange data and formula in a matrix of cells.
Refers to software that manipulates data in the ledger-style format and carries out calculations from formula stored in cells of electronic "sheet".
Equally spaced holes on both edges of continuous paper to feed paper through a printer.
Statistical Package for Social Sciences.
Refers to a signal that is made Up of alternate binary one's and zero's.
Small Scale Integration.
When data is added at the end of a list and is retrieved from the same end.
It is a register that contains address in main memory. The stack can be stored here and can be retrieved later on.
A partition of the software development cycle that represents a meaningful and measurable set of related tasks which are performed to obtain specific work products, or deliverables. See deliverable .

One of the generic processes of the Shell Method SDLC. The stage exit is the vehicle for securing the concurrence of principal project participants to continue with the project and move forward into the next stage of development. The purpose of a stage exit is to allow all personnel involved with the project to review the current stage deliverables, provide a forum to raise issues and concerns, and to ensure an acceptable action plan exists for all open issues.
The process of moving data from one- storage device to another is having shorter access time.
Those individuals with decision-making authority over a project or group of projects.

(1) Refers to a device that operates separately. (2) Pertaining to hardware or software that is capable of performing its function without being connected to other components; for example, a stand-alone word processing system.
Procedures and rules employed and enforced to prescribe a disciplined, uniform approach to software development.
Any peripheral device that needs to be connected to the CPU through standard interface that are standard form of plug and jack.
Precise, defined rules, activities, and practices developed by an organization to consistently manage normal operations.

(1) Approved reference models and protocols as determined by standard-setting groups to prescribe a disciplined, uniform approach to software development and maintenance. (2) (IEEE Std 983-1986 [71) Mandatory requirements employed and enforced to prescribe a disciplined uniform approach to software development, that is, mandatory conventions and practices are in fact standards. See also: practices; standards.
In fault tolerance, the use of redundant elements that are left inoperative until a failure occurs in a primary element. Contrast with: active redundancy.
See: idle time.
It was the first mechanical calculator that was based on geared wheels and designed for arithmetical operations in 1775.
It is a communications control character. It indicates the beginning of headers in a message.
It is a communications control character. It indicates that headers have been sent and that the text data contains the information that is to be sent.

The address of the first instruction of a computer program in main storage. Note: This address may or may not be the same as the program's origin, depending upon whether there are data preceding the first instruction. Contrast with: origin. See also: assembled origin; loaded origin.

(1) A condition or mode of existence that a system, component, or simulation may be in; for example, the pre-flight state of an aircraft navigation program or the input state of given channel. (2) The values assumed at a given instant by the variables that define the characteristics of a system, component, or simulation.
(IEEE Std 1008-1987 [lo]) Data that defines an internal state of the test unit and is used to establish that state or compare with existing states.
A diagram that depicts the states that a system or component can assume, and shows the events or circumstances that cause or result from a change from one state to another.
A communications control character indicating the beginning of a message.
A graphical representation of the states of a system and the way transitions from one state to another occur. See: state diagram.

(1) In high-level language it refers to a single unit of program command. (2) In a programming language, a meaningful expression that defines data, specifies program actions, or directs the assembler or compiler. See also: assignment statement; control statement; declaration.
Testing designed to execute each statement of a computer program. Contrast with: branch testing; path testing.
Pertaining to an event or process that occurs without computer program execution; for example, static analysis, static binding. Contrast with: dynamic.
The process of evaluating a system or component based on its form, structure, content, or documentation. Contrast with: dynamic analysis. See also: inspection; walk-through.
Binding performed prior to the execution of a computer program and not subject to change during program execution. Contrast with: dynamic binding.

A breakpoint that can be set at compile time, such as entry into a given routine. Contrast with: dynamic breakpoint. See also: code bmakpoint; data breakpoint; epilog breakpoint; programmable breakpoint; pmlog breakpoint.
A dump that is produced before or after the execution of a computer program. Contrast with: dynamic dump. See also: change dump; memory dump; postmortem dump; selective dump; snapshot dump.
An error that is independent of the time-varying nature of an input. Contrast with: dynamic error.
RAM that does not need continual memory refresh from the processor.
A code used to indicate the results of a computer program operation. For example, a code indicating a carry, an overflow, or a parity error. Syn: condition code.

The period of time that begins with the decision to develop a software product and ends when the software is delivered. This cycle typically includes a requirements phase, design phase, implementation phase, test phase, and sometimes, installation and checkout phase. Contrast with: software life cycle. Notes: (1) The phases listed above may overlap or be performed iteratively, depending upon the software development approach used. (2) This term is sometimes used to mean a longer period of time, either the period that ends when the software is no longer being enhanced by the developer, or the entire software life cycle.
One instruction in a computer routine.
See: single-step operation.

A software development technique in which data and processing steps are defined broadly at first and then further defined with increasing detail. See also: data structure-centered design; inputprocessoutput; modular decomposition; object-oriented design; rapid prototyping structured design; transaction analysis; transform analysis.
To terminate the execution of a computer program. Syn: halt (1). Contrust with: pause.

(1) To assign space to a program in the main memory or on an external storage device. (2) An element of computer resource allocation, consisting of assigning storage areas to specific jobs and performing related procedures, such as transfer of data between main and auxiliary storage, to support the assignments made. See also: buffer; contiguous allocation; cyclic search; memory compaction; overlay; paging; virtual storage.
See: data breakpoint.

(1) It is the maximum amount of information that can be stored in any device. (2) The maximum number of items that can be held in a given storage device; usually measured in words or bytes. See also: channel capacity; memory capacity.

(1) To place or retain data in a storage device. (2) To copy computer instructions or data from a register to internal storage or from internal storage to external storage. Contrast with: load (2). See also: fetch; move.
It is a digital computer that stores instructions in memory and can be programmed to change its run in striations and subsequently execute them in their altered form.
(1) Refers to those instructions that are executed in a sequence without repetition. (2) A sequence of computer instructions in which there are no loops.
A programming technique in which loops are avoided by stating explicitly and in full all of the instructions that would be involved in the execution of each loop. See also: unwind.
A language that cannot be used as its own metalanguage. Examples include FORTRAN, COBOL. Contrast with: unstratified language.
Testing conducted to evaluate a system or component at or beyond the limits of its specified requirements. See also: boundary value.
It is a connected sequence of characters or bits treated as a single data item. e.g. the word computer in a string of eight words.
Refers to a set of record keys in a descending or ascending order.
Refers to the process of performing various string operations.
It is a fast pulse that signals when data is to be transferred.

A feature of some programming languages that requires the type of each data item to be declared, precludes the application of operators to inappropriate data types, and prevents the interaction of data items of incompatible types.

Testing that takes into account the internal mechanism of a system or component. Types include branch testing, path testing, statement testing. Syn: glassbox testing; white-box testing. Contrast with: functional testing (1).

(1) A graphic chart for depicting the partitioning of a software system into modules, the hierarchy and organization of these modules, and the communication interfaces between the modules. (2) A diagram that identifies modules, activities, or other entities in a system or computer program and shows how larger or more general entities break down System Subsystem Q Subsystem Q laProgram Fig 16 structurechart structure clash. In software design, a situation in which a module must deal with two or more data sets that have incompatible data structures. See also: data structure-centered design; order clash.

(1) A disciplined approach to requirements specification that stresses the development of a maintainable specification and communication with the user. The analysis is based on a technique using control flow diagrams, data flow diagram, a data dictionary, and process specifications, as applicable, to define system inputs, processes, and outputs. (2) A top-down method for defining system inputs, processes, and outputs to build models of software products or systems. The four basic features in structured analysis are data flow diagrams, data dictionaries, procedure logic descriptions, and data store descriptions.

(1) Any disciplined approach to software design that adheres to specified rules based on principles such as modularity, top-down design, and stepwise refinement of data, system structures, and processing steps. See also: data structurecentered design; input-process-output; modular decomposition; object-oriented design; rapid prototyping; stepwise refinement; transaction analysis; transform analysis. (2) The result of applying the approach in (1). (3) A disciplined approach to the design of software based on a hierarchical decomposition and implementation of system functions into software modules. Structured design has as one of its goals to maximize cohesiveness and minimize coupling.

Software development methods that are concerned with components of a system and the interrelationship between these components. Structured methods include structured analysis, structured design, and structured programming.

A computer program constructed of a basic set of control structures, each having one entry and one exit. The set of control structures typically includes: sequence of two or more instructions, conditional selection of one of two or more sequences of instructions, and repetition of a sequence of instructions. See also: structured design.

(1) A welldefined software development technique that normally incorporates strict use and implementation of three basis control constructs: sequence; selection; and repetition. (2) Any software development technique that includes strucn the subtype are the same as those of the original data type. See also: derived type.

A programming language that provides the structured program constructs, namely, singleentry-single-exit sequences, branches, and loops, and facilitates the development of structured programs. See also: blockstructured language.
A standard data definition and data manipulation language for relational database management systems.

(1) A skeletal or special-purpose implementation of a software module, used to develop or test a module that calls or is otherwise dependent on it. (2) A computer program statement substituting for the body of a software module that is or will be defined elsewhere.(3) Refers to a substitute component that is used temporarily. In a program so that progress can be made,
Start of Text.
(1) Lower level design components; (2) The components of the components.
A manufacturer or supplier to a production agency, contractor, or to another subcontractor, who will provide major components or special designed items for the DOE.

A person, generally a customer staff member, who is considered to be an expert in one or more operational processes that are the focus of an automation effort. SMEs are generally the primary sources of application requirements, and play very significant roles in the requirements, design, and testing stages of the software development lifecycle.

(1) A major functional subset of a program made up of one or more modules. (2) A separately compilable, executable component of a computer program. Note: The terms routine, subprogram and subroutine are defined and used differently in different programming languages; the preceding definition is advanced as a proposed standard. See also: coroutine; main program; routine; subroutine.
Any SQL Select statement that's included (nested) within another Select, Insert, Update, or Delete statement or nested within another subquery.

(1) It is a section of a program written to carry out specific task which the main program may use either once or many a times during its run. (2) A routine that returns control to the program or subprogram that called it. Note: The terms routine, subprogram and subroutine are defined and used differently in different programming languages; the preceding definition is advanced as a proposed standard. Contrast with: coroutine. See also: closed subroutine; open submutine.

A record of all or selected subroutines or function calls performed during the execution of a computer program and, optionally, the values of parameters passed to and returned by each subroutine or function. Syn: call trace. See also: execution trace; retrospective trace; subroutine trace; symbolic trace; variable trace.
Those characters which are printed higher than the normal character. E.g. in H2O,2 is a subscript character.
The actual structural material on which semi-conductor devices are fabricated.
A secondary or subordinate system with a larger system.

A subset of a data type, obtained by constraining the set of possible values of the data type. Note: The operations applicable to supervisor. See: supervisory program supervisor state, In the operation of a computer system, a state in which the supervisory program is executing. This state usually has higher priority than, and precludes the execution of, application programs. Syn: executive state; master state; privileged state. Contrast with: problem State.

An extremely fast computer capable of processing both scalar and vector quantities. It can carry out many carry out many a thousand operations simultaneously and can carry out billions of additions per second,
Refers to a conductor that has a very low resistance and can support very fast communications without all appreciable attenuation or distortion in the message.
Ultra high density cl1ips containing one million or more components per chip.
Software package used for word processing of Radio shack TRS-80 micro-computer systems.

(1) It is a machine language program that is stored inside a computer It keeps the over all data processing system operating at nearly peak efficiency. (2) A computer program, usually part of an operating system, that controls the execution of other computer programs and regulates the flow of work in a computer system. Syn: control program; executive; executive program; supervisor. See also: supervisor state.

The set of activities necessary to ensure that an operational system or component fulfills its original requirements and any subsequent modifications to those requirements. For example, software or hardware maintenance, user training. See also: software life cycle; system life cycle.

Activities that make the delivery of the primary services or products of a firm possible. These activities typically focus on support of the organization's infrastructure, human resources, technologies, and logistics.

A component in a database application that supports the maintenance of data used primarily for reference and support of operational data areas. For example, in an order entry system, the maintenance of lists of customer business types or order shipment methods would be considered support data areas. See operational data area.

A document that provides the information necessary to service and maintain an operational system or component throughout its life cycle. Typically described are the hardware and software that make up the system or component and procedures for servicing, repairing, or reprogramming it. Syn: maintenance manual. See also: diagnostic manual; installation manual; operator manual; programmer manual; user manual.

(1) A computer program, and associated documentation, used in general support of the processes of a computer (such as diagnostic, copy, trace, or sort programs), or to assist in software design (such as CASE Tools, test software, development systems, and compilers). (2) Software that aids in the development or maintenance of other software, for example, compilers, loaders, and other utilities. Contrast with: application software. See also: system software.
It is a system program that monitors the use of a resource on behalf of system security.

(1) An exchange of the contents of two storage areas, usually an area of main storage with an area of auxiliary storage. See also: roll in; roll out. (2) To perform an exchange as in (1).
Means to move a program from auxiliary storage into main memory for execution.
Means to move a program into auxiliary storage to await further execution'
It is a software program that guides the computer system in writing, editing and formatting text.
Several program bugs.
It refers to a situation where in the images displayed on a video display screen move due to some hardware instability or defect.
Refers to the point at which a program may branch to one or more different program statements, depending upon the conditions of specified parameters at that point.
A table that presents program symbols and their corresponding addresses, values, and other attributes.
An address expressed as a name or label that must be translated to the absolute address of the device or storage Iocation to be accessed. Contrast with: absolute address.
Programming code which uses numeric names for instructions e.g. SUB for Subtract.
The coding in which instructions are written in non-machine language.
System program that helps computer users in the preparation and modification of source language programs by adding, changing or deleting lines of text.

A software analysis technique in which program execution is simulated using symbols, such as variable names, rather than actual values for input data, and program outputs are expressed as logical or mathematical expressions involving these symbols.

A programming language that expresses operations and addresses in symbols convenient to humans rather than in machine language. Examples are assembly language, high order language. Contrast with: machine language.

A record of the source statements and branch outcomes that are encountered when a computer program is executed using symbolic, rather than actual, values for input data. See also: execution trace; retrospective trace; subroutine trace; variable trace.
Contrast with: semantic error.
Input signals from one neuron other neurons are received through adjustable connections known as synapses.
III synchronous transmission a character that is periodically transmitted to the receiving device as a check or its synchronisation with the sending device.

(1) A process of maintaining one or more operations in step with each other. (2) Refers to the relationship between processes in such a way that one process can not proceed beyond a particular point until another process has reached a particular point
The performance of a computer whereby the start of every operation is dependent on a pulse from its internal clock.
A violation of the structural or grammatical rules defined for a language; for example, using the statement B + C = A in Fortran, rather than the correct A = B + C.

(1) Rules to help understanding. These rules govern the way in which program instructions are structured. Statements will not be executed if they are not correctly formulated.(2) The structural or grammatical rules that define how the symbols in a language are to be combined to form words, phrases, expressions, and other allowable constructs. Contrast with: semantics.
Refers to an error that is caused due if to a violation of the syntax of a particular language. It can be detected by the language processor when the program is translated into machine language.
Micro-processor controlled output device that generates and processes sound automatically.
See: generated address.
Refers to the principal input stream of an operating system.
(1) The total of ail things that make up the working computer unit. (2) A collection of components organized to accomplish a specific function or set of functi ons.

(1) A collection of hardware, software, firmware, and documentation components organized to accomplish a specific function or set of related functions. (2) An Integrated whole that is composed of diverse, interacting specialized structures, performing many duties by functioning as a single entity.
The evaluation coupled, if necessary, with the design and installation of a computer system for solving a problem.
Refers to some one who evaluates the needs of a computing application and recommends hardware, software etc
The bus that carries data between various units in a computer.

A review conducted to evaluate the manner in which the requirements for a system have been allocated to configuration items, the system engineering process that produced the allocation, the engineering planning for the next phase of the effort, manufacturing considerations, and the planning for production engineering. See also: critical design review; preliminary design review.

A stage in the software development lifecycle during which the requirements for the software product architecture, components, interfaces, and data structures are refined and expanded to the extent that the design is sufficiently complete to be implemented. Also known as the Design stage .

The period of time that begins with the decision to develop a system and ends when the system is delivered to its end user. Note: This term is sometimes used to mean a longer period of time, either the period that ends when the system is no longer being enhanced, or the entire system life cycle. Contrast with: system life cycle. See also: software development cycle.
Refers to programs which are used to Eject overall system malfunctions.
A disk reserved for storage of programs and data used by the operating system and of various other system programs.
See: flowchart.
The process of initiating a required system out of specific installation.
Means a break in the normal execution of a program or routine that is accomplished in such a way that the usual sequence can be resumed from the point.

A software library containing system-resident software that can be accessed for use or incorporated into other programs by reference; for example, a macro library. Contrast with: master library; production library; software development library; software repository.
The period of time that begins when a system is conceived and ends when the system is no longer available for use. See also: system development cycle; software life cycle.
The individual or organization or group who provides technical support for the management and operation of computer systems.
In computer performance evaluation, a representation of a system depicting the relationships between workloads and performance measures in the system. See also: workload model.
It is the percentage of time that a computer system functions as a supervisor rather than in the performance of an actual program.
The organizational unit or person that provides funding and has approval authority for the project. Also referred to as the customer or client. Typically, system owners are also system users.

A set of measurements used in computer performance evaluation, describing the proportion of time each of the major resources in a computer system is busy, divided by the time that resource is avail ab1 e.
See: block diagram.

(1) Software that controls the execution of computer programs and may provide scheduling, debugging, inputoutput, accounting, compilation, storage assignment and data management. [see operating system]. (2) Specialized programs that manage the resources of the computer, such as the central processor, communication links, and peripheral devices. See operating system . (3) Refers to software which performs tasks for system itself. (4) Software designed to facilitate the operation and maintenance of a computer system and its associated programs; for example, operating systems, assemblers, utilities. Contrast with: application software. See also: support software.

(1) Testing of the application or information system as a whole to determine if discrete components will function together as planned and to evaluate compliance with specified requirements. (2) Testing conducted on a complete, integrated system to evaluate the system's compliance with its specified requirements. See also: component testing; integration testing; interface testing; unit testing.

(1) The analysis of a problem that the organization will try to solve with an information system. (2) Specialists who translate business problems and requirements into information systems requirements, acting as a bridge between the information systems department, the system owner, and end-users.

Refers to magnetic tape. A magnetic tape is used to store information transmitted from computer. Paper tapes are also used for this purpose. In case of magnetic tapes data is generally stored in blocks. In this the computer checks each block in addition to checking the parity bit of each character.

Refers to the disk to which a program or file is copied.

(1) Refers to the language in which some other language is to be translated. (2) The language in which the output from a machine-aided translation process is represented. For example, the language output by an assembler or compiler. Syn: object language. Contrast with: source language.
(1) The computer on which a program is intended to execute. Contrast with: host machine (1). (2) A computer being emulated by another computer. Contrast with: host machine (2).
See: object program.
It is the rate that is charged to customers for using communication channel provided by a common carrier.

(1) A sequence of instructions treated as a basic unit of work by the supervisory program of an operating system. Refers to the information required to manage the concurrent execution of programs like the priority assigned the partition for their execution, their status etc.

(IEEE Std 1002-1987 [91) The application of technical and admintechnical standard. (IEEE Std 1002-1987 [91) A standard that describes the characteristics of applying accumulated technical or management skills and methods in the creation of a product or performing a service.
The review of a deliverable for techical accuracy by a qualified developer who is familiar with the software product under design or development. See Review .

(1) A systematic means of achieving a desired goal. [contrast with methodology]. (2) (IEEE Std 983-1 986 [71) Technical and managerial procedures that aid in the evaluation and improvement of the software development process.

Software and hardware tools and services used to develop and support a database application. (1) An activity in which a system or component is executed under specified conditions, the results are observed or recorded, and an evaluation is made of some aspect of the system or component. (2) To conduct an activity as in (1). (3) (IEEE Std 829-1983 [51) A set of one or more test cases. (4) (IEEE Std 829-1983 [SI) A set of one or more test procedures. (5) (IEEE Std 829-1983 [51) A set of one or more test cases and procedures.
An environment containing the hardware, instrumentation, simulators, software tools, and other support elements needed to conduct a test.

(1) A set of test inputs, execution conditions, and expected results developed for a particular objective, such as to exercise a particular program path or to verify compliance with a specific requirement. (2) (IEEE Std 829-1983 153) Documentation specifying inputs, predicted results, and a set of execution conditions for a test item. See also: test case generator; test case specification. (3) A specific test definition developed for a particular objective or to verify a particular characteristic of the software. Test cases include test data, objectives, and expected outcomes. (4) A defined set of database records, test inputs, execution conditions and anticipated results designed to exercise specific application components and verify compliance with design criteria and requirements. Contains detailed instructions for the set up, execution, and evaluation of the results for the test case.

A software tool that accepts as input source code, test criteria, specifications, or data structure definitions; uses these inputs to generate test input data; and, sometimes, determines expected results. Syn: test data generator; test generator.

A document that specifies the test inputs, execution conditions, and predicted results for an item to be tested. Syn: test description; test specification. See also: test incident report; test item transmittal report; test log; test plan; test procedure; test coverage. The degree to which a given test or set of tests addresses all specified requirements for a given system or component.

The criteria that a system or com- test objective. (IEEE Std 1008-1987 [loll An ponent must meet in order to pass a given identified set of software features to be test. Documentation describing plans for, or results of, the testing of a system or component. Types include test case specification, test incident report, test log, test plan, test procedure, test report.
A software module used to invoke a module under test and, often, provide test inputs, control and monitor execution, and report test results. Syn: test harness.
See: test case generator.
See: test driver.

A document that describes an event that occurred during testing which requires further investigation. See also: test case specification; test item transmittal report; test log; test plan; test procedure; test Ireport.
(1) A software component that is the object of a test case. (2) (IEEE Std 829-1983 151) A software item which is an object of testing.

(IEEE Std 829-1983 [51) A document that identifies one or more items submitted for testing. It contains current status and location information. See also: test case specification; test incident report; test log; test plan; test procedure; test report, test log. A chronological record of all relevant details about the execution of a test. The period of time in the software life cycle during which the components of a software product are evaluated and integrated, and the software product is evaluated to determine whether or not requirements have been satisfied. test plan. (1) (IEEE Std 829-1983 [51) A document describing the scope, approach, resources, and schedule of intended test activities. Typical contents identify the items to be tested, tasks to beperformed, responsibilities, schedulesand required resources for the testing activity. (1) A written document that outlines the methods and philosophy to be followed in testing the software. (2) A document that defines the preparations, test items, test data, and test cases for the series of tests to be performed on an application.

(1) Detailed instructions for the set-up, execution, and evaluation of results for a given test case. (2) A document containing a set of associated instructions as in (1). (3) (IEEE Std 829-1983 153) Documentation specifying a sequence of actions for the execution of a test. Syn: test procedure specification; test script. (4) Documentation specifying a sequence of actions necessary to conduct a particular test, using a specific set of test cases. A test procedure may apply to more than one test case.

(1) A review conducted to evaluate preliminary test results for one or more configuration items; to verify that the test procedures for each configuration item are complete, comply with test plans and descriptions, and satisfy test requirements; and to verify that a project is prepared to proceed to formal testing of the Configuration items. (2) A review as in (1) for any hardware or software component. Contrast with: code review; formal qualification review; design review; requirements review.
An attribute of a test, indicating that the same results are produced each time the test is conducted.

A document that describes the conduct and results of the testing carried out for a system or component. Syn: test summary report. See also: test case specification; test incident report; test item transmittal report; test log; test plan; test procedure.
A document that contains a chronological record of the execution and results of the testing carried out for a software component or application.

(IEEE Std 1008-1987 [lo]) The nested relationships between sets of test cases that directly reflect the hierarchic decomposition of the test objectives.

(IEEE Std 829-1983 [5]) A document summarizing testing activities and results. It also contains an evaluation think time. A group of persons responsible for the development, execution, and proper documentation of the Test Plan.

(IEEE Std 1008-1987 [lo]) A set of one or more computer program modules together with associated control data, (for example, tables), usage procedures, and operating procedures that satisfy the following conditions: (a) All modules are from a single computer program; (b) At least one of the new or changed modules in the set has not completed the unit test; (c) The set of modules together with its associated data and procedures are the sole object of a testing process.

(1) The degree to which a system or component facilitates the establishment of test criteria and the performance of tests to determine whether those criteria have been met. (1) The process of exercising a system (or some component) to identify differences between expected and actual results. Also often referred to as the test and acceptance stage. A stage in the software development lifecycle where the components of a software product are executed under specified conditions, the results are observed and recorded, and an evaluation is made to determine whether or not the requirements have been met.

Acronym for User Datagram Protocol. The con- nectionless protocol within TCP/IP that corresponds to the transport layer in the ISO/OSI reference model. UDP con- verts data messages generated by an application into pack- ets to be sent via IP, but it is unreliable because it does not establish a path between sender and receiver before transmitting and does not verify that messages have been delivered correctly. UDP is more efficient than TCP, so it is used for various purposes, including SNMP; the reliability depends on the application that generates the message. See also communications protocol, ISO/OSI reference model, packet, SNMP, TCP/IP. Compare IP, TCP.

Acronym for uninterruptible power supply. A device, connected between a computer (or other electronic equipment) and a power source (usually an outlet recepta- cle), that ensures that electrical flow to the computer is not interrupted because of a blackout and, in most cases, pro- tects the computer against potentially damaging events, such as power surges and brownouts. All UPS units are equipped with a battery and a loss-of-power sensor; if the sensor detects a loss of power, it switches over to the bat- tery so that the user has time to save his or her work and shut off the computer. See also blackout, brownout.

A document that accompanies and identifies a given version of a system or component. Typical contents include an inventory of system or component parts, identification of changes incorporated into this version, and installation and operating information unique to the version described.

A number assigned by a software developer to identify a particular program at a particular stage, before and after public release. Successive public releases of a program are assigned increasingly higher numbers. Version numbers usually include decimal frac- tions. Major changes are generally marked by a change in the whole number, whereas for minor changes only the number after the decimal point increases.

A microinstruction that specifies one of a sequence of operations needed to carry out a machine language instruction. Note: Vertical microinstructions are relatively short, 12 to 24 bits, and are called vertical because a sequence of such instruction, normally listed vertically on a page, are required to carry out a single machine language instruction. Contrast with: diagonal microinstruction; horizontal microinstruction.

(1) It is a technique for managing execution of program by utilizing limited quantity of internal storage and a much larger quantity of lower-speed external storage in such a way the distinction is quite transparent to a computer user Virtual Storage Access Method (VSAM). (2) A storage allocation technique in which auxiliary storage can be addressed as though it were part of main storage. Portions of a users program and data are placed in auxiliary storage, and the operating system automatically swaps them in and out of main storage as needed. Syn: multilevel storage, virtual memory. Contrast with: real storage. See also: virtual address; paging (2).

(1) Refers to a product review that is performed by a formal team. (2) An informal review technique (usually less structured than inspections) in which the designed (or author) guides participants through an examination of software for problems. Walkthroughs may be conducted on requirements, design documentation, plans, code, test results, and so forth. [contrast with inspection]. (3) A static analysis technique in which a designer or programmer leads members of the development team and other interested parties through a segment of documentation or code, and the participants ask questions and make comments about possible errors, violation of development standards, and other problems. (4) The review of a functional element, design element, or implementation element by a team of subject matter experts to detect possible errors, violation of development standards, and other problems.

(1) A model of the software life cycle in which the time periods or phases of the life cycle are arranged as the cascades in a waterfall. The software life cycle typically includes a concept exploration phase, a requirements phase, design phase, implementation phase, test phase, installation and checkout phase, operation and maintenance phase, and retirement phase. (2) A model of the software development process in which the constituent activities, typically a concept phase, requirements phase, design phase, implementation phase, test phase, and installation and checkout phase, are performed in that order, possibly with overlap but with little or no iteration. Contrast with: incremental development; rapid pmtotyping; spiral modeL wearout-failure period. Acronym for What You See Before You Get It. Providing a preview of the effects of the changes the user has selected before the changes are finally applied. For example, a dialog box in a word processing program might display a sample of the font a user has chosen before the font is actually changed in the document. The user can can- cel any changes after previewing them, and the document will be unaffected. See also WYSIWYG.

Acronym for What You See Is What You Get, pronounced "WIZZING". Allowing a user to view a document as it will appear in the final product, and to directly edit the text, graphics, or other elements within that view. A WYSIWYG language is often easier to use than a markup language, which provides no immediate visual feedback regarding the changes being made. Com- pare markup language.
